#!/usr/bin/env bash
set -euo pipefail

# spot-diggz ã‚·ãƒ¼ã‚¯ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆå–å¾—ã‚¹ã‚¯ãƒªãƒ—ãƒˆ
# 1Password CLI (op) ã‚’ä½¿ã£ã¦ .env.tpl ã‹ã‚‰ .env ã‚’ç”Ÿæˆã™ã‚‹

SCRIPT_DIR="$(cd "$(dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}")" && pwd)"
PROJECT_ROOT="$(cd "${SCRIPT_DIR}/../.." && pwd)"

# è‰²ä»˜ãå‡ºåŠ›
RED='\033[0;31m'
GREEN='\033[0;32m'
YELLOW='\033[0;33m'
NC='\033[0m' # No Color

info()  { echo -e "${GREEN}[INFO]${NC} $*"; }
warn()  { echo -e "${YELLOW}[WARN]${NC} $*"; }
error() { echo -e "${RED}[ERROR]${NC} $*" >&2; }

# op CLI ã®å­˜åœ¨ãƒã‚§ãƒƒã‚¯
check_op_cli() {
  if ! command -v op &> /dev/null; then
    error "1Password CLI (op) ãŒã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ¼ãƒ«ã•ã‚Œã¦ã„ã¾ã›ã‚“"
    echo ""
    echo "ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ¼ãƒ«æ–¹æ³•:"
    echo "  macOS:   brew install --cask 1password-cli"
    echo "  Linux:   https://developer.1password.com/docs/cli/get-started/"
    echo ""
    exit 1
  fi
}

# op CLI ã®èªè¨¼ãƒã‚§ãƒƒã‚¯
check_op_auth() {
  if ! op account list &> /dev/null 2>&1; then
    error "1Password CLI ãŒæœªèªè¨¼ã§ã™"
    echo ""
    echo "ã‚µã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¤ãƒ³æ–¹æ³•:"
    echo "  eval \$(op signin)"
    echo ""
    echo "1Password ãƒ‡ã‚¹ã‚¯ãƒˆãƒƒãƒ—ã‚¢ãƒ—ãƒªã¨ã®é€£æºã‚’æ¨å¥¨:"
    echo "  1Password > è¨­å®š > é–‹ç™ºè€… > ã€ŒCLI ã¨ãƒ‡ã‚¹ã‚¯ãƒˆãƒƒãƒ—ã‚¢ãƒ—ãƒªã‚’é€£æºã€ã‚’æœ‰åŠ¹åŒ–"
    echo ""
    exit 1
  fi
}

# Vault ã®å­˜åœ¨ãƒã‚§ãƒƒã‚¯
check_vault() {
  local vault_name="$1"
  if ! op vault get "${vault_name}" &> /dev/null 2>&1; then
    error "Vault '${vault_name}' ãŒè¦‹ã¤ã‹ã‚Šã¾ã›ã‚“"
    echo ""
    echo "Vault ã‚’ä½œæˆã—ã¦ãã ã•ã„:"
    echo "  op vault create '${vault_name}'"
    echo ""
    echo "å¿…è¦ãªã‚¢ã‚¤ãƒ†ãƒ ã®ä½œæˆæ–¹æ³•ã¯ docs/secrets_management.md ã‚’å‚ç…§ã—ã¦ãã ã•ã„"
    exit 1
  fi
}

# .env.tpl ã‹ã‚‰ .env ã‚’ç”Ÿæˆ
inject_env() {
  local tpl_file="$1"
  local out_file="$2"
  local label="$3"

  if [[ ! -f "${tpl_file}" ]]; then
    error "ãƒ†ãƒ³ãƒ—ãƒ¬ãƒ¼ãƒˆãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚¤ãƒ«ãŒè¦‹ã¤ã‹ã‚Šã¾ã›ã‚“: ${tpl_file}"
    return 1
  fi

  info "${label}: ${tpl_file} â†’ ${out_file}"
  op inject -i "${tpl_file}" -o "${out_file}" --force
  info "${label}: ç”Ÿæˆå®Œäº†"
}

# å‹•çš„ãƒˆãƒ¼ã‚¯ãƒ³ã®å–å¾—ãƒ»è¿½è¨˜
inject_dynamic_tokens() {
  local env_file="$1"

  if ! command -v gcloud &> /dev/null; then
    warn "gcloud CLI ãŒè¦‹ã¤ã‹ã‚Šã¾ã›ã‚“ã€‚SDZ_FIRESTORE_TOKEN / SDZ_STORAGE_SIGNING_TOKEN ã¯æ‰‹å‹•ã§è¨­å®šã—ã¦ãã ã•ã„"
    return 0
  fi

  info "gcloud access token ã‚’å–å¾—ä¸­..."
  local token
  token=$(gcloud auth print-access-token 2>/dev/null) || {
    warn "gcloud auth print-access-token ã«å¤±æ•—ã—ã¾ã—ãŸã€‚gcloud auth login ã‚’å®Ÿè¡Œã—ã¦ãã ã•ã„"
    return 0
  }

  # sed ã§ REPLACE_BY_SCRIPT ã‚’å®Ÿéš›ã®ãƒˆãƒ¼ã‚¯ãƒ³ã«ç½®æ›
  if [[ "$(uname)" == "Darwin" ]]; then
    sed -i '' "s|SDZ_FIRESTORE_TOKEN=REPLACE_BY_SCRIPT|SDZ_FIRESTORE_TOKEN=${token}|" "${env_file}"
    sed -i '' "s|SDZ_STORAGE_SIGNING_TOKEN=REPLACE_BY_SCRIPT|SDZ_STORAGE_SIGNING_TOKEN=${token}|" "${env_file}"
  else
    sed -i "s|SDZ_FIRESTORE_TOKEN=REPLACE_BY_SCRIPT|SDZ_FIRESTORE_TOKEN=${token}|" "${env_file}"
    sed -i "s|SDZ_STORAGE_SIGNING_TOKEN=REPLACE_BY_SCRIPT|SDZ_STORAGE_SIGNING_TOKEN=${token}|" "${env_file}"
  fi
  info "å‹•çš„ãƒˆãƒ¼ã‚¯ãƒ³ã‚’ .env ã«æ³¨å…¥ã—ã¾ã—ãŸ"
}

# ãƒ¡ã‚¤ãƒ³å‡¦ç†
main() {
  echo "=== spot-diggz ã‚·ãƒ¼ã‚¯ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆå–å¾— ==="
  echo ""

  check_op_cli
  check_op_auth
  check_vault "sdz-dev"

  echo ""

  # API ç’°å¢ƒå¤‰æ•°
  inject_env \
    "${PROJECT_ROOT}/web/api/.env.tpl" \
    "${PROJECT_ROOT}/web/api/.env" \
    "API"

  # å‹•çš„ãƒˆãƒ¼ã‚¯ãƒ³ã®æ³¨å…¥
  inject_dynamic_tokens "${PROJECT_ROOT}/web/api/.env"

  echo ""

  # UI ç’°å¢ƒå¤‰æ•°
  inject_env \
    "${PROJECT_ROOT}/web/ui/.env.tpl" \
    "${PROJECT_ROOT}/web/ui/.env.local" \

#!/usr/bin/env bash
set -euo pipefail

# spot-diggz ã‚·ãƒ¼ã‚¯ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆå–å¾—ã‚¹ã‚¯ãƒªãƒ—ãƒˆ
# 1Password CLI (op) ã‚’ä½¿ã£ã¦ .env.tpl ã‹ã‚‰ .env ã‚’ç”Ÿæˆã™ã‚‹

SCRIPT_DIR="$(cd "$(dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}")" && pwd)"
PROJECT_ROOT="$(cd "${SCRIPT_DIR}/../.." && pwd)"

# è‰²ä»˜ãå‡ºåŠ›
RED='\033[0;31m'
GREEN='\033[0;32m'
YELLOW='\033[0;33m'
NC='\033[0m' # No Color

info()  { echo -e "${GREEN}[INFO]${NC} $*"; }
warn()  { echo -e "${YELLOW}[WARN]${NC} $*"; }
error() { echo -e "${RED}[ERROR]${NC} $*" >&2; }

# op CLI ã®å­˜åœ¨ãƒã‚§ãƒƒã‚¯
check_op_cli() {
  if ! command -v op &> /dev/null; then
    error "1Password CLI (op) ãŒã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ¼ãƒ«ã•ã‚Œã¦ã„ã¾ã›ã‚“"
    echo ""
    echo "ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ¼ãƒ«æ–¹æ³•:"
    echo "  macOS:   brew install --cask 1password-cli"
    echo "  Linux:   https://developer.1password.com/docs/cli/get-started/"
    echo ""
    exit 1
  fi
}

# op CLI ã®èªè¨¼ãƒã‚§ãƒƒã‚¯
check_op_auth() {
  if ! op account list &> /dev/null 2>&1; then
    error "1Password CLI ãŒæœªèªè¨¼ã§ã™"
    echo ""
    echo "ã‚µã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¤ãƒ³æ–¹æ³•:"
    echo "  eval \$(op signin)"
    echo ""
    echo "1Password ãƒ‡ã‚¹ã‚¯ãƒˆãƒƒãƒ—ã‚¢ãƒ—ãƒªã¨ã®é€£æºã‚’æ¨å¥¨:"
    echo "  1Password > è¨­å®š > é–‹ç™ºè€… > ã€ŒCLI ã¨ãƒ‡ã‚¹ã‚¯ãƒˆãƒƒãƒ—ã‚¢ãƒ—ãƒªã‚’é€£æºã€ã‚’æœ‰åŠ¹åŒ–"
    echo ""
    exit 1
  fi
}

# Vault ã®å­˜åœ¨ãƒã‚§ãƒƒã‚¯
check_vault() {
  local vault_name="$1"
  if ! op vault get "${vault_name}" &> /dev/null 2>&1; then
    error "Vault '${vault_name}' ãŒè¦‹ã¤ã‹ã‚Šã¾ã›ã‚“"
    echo ""
    echo "Vault ã‚’ä½œæˆã—ã¦ãã ã•ã„:"
    echo "  op vault create '${vault_name}'"
    echo ""
    echo "å¿…è¦ãªã‚¢ã‚¤ãƒ†ãƒ ã®ä½œæˆæ–¹æ³•ã¯ docs/secrets_management.md ã‚’å‚ç…§ã—ã¦ãã ã•ã„"
    exit 1
  fi
}

# .env.tpl ã‹ã‚‰ .env ã‚’ç”Ÿæˆ
inject_env() {
  local tpl_file="$1"
  local out_file="$2"
  local label="$3"

  if [[ ! -f "${tpl_file}" ]]; then
    error "ãƒ†ãƒ³ãƒ—ãƒ¬ãƒ¼ãƒˆãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚¤ãƒ«ãŒè¦‹ã¤ã‹ã‚Šã¾ã›ã‚“: ${tpl_file}"
    return 1
  fi

  info "${label}: ${tpl_file} â†’ ${out_file}"
  op inject -i "${tpl_file}" -o "${out_file}" --force
  info "${label}: ç”Ÿæˆå®Œäº†"
}

# å‹•çš„ãƒˆãƒ¼ã‚¯ãƒ³ã®å–å¾—ãƒ»è¿½è¨˜
inject_dynamic_tokens() {
  local env_file="$1"

  if ! command -v gcloud &> /dev/null; then
    warn "gcloud CLI ãŒè¦‹ã¤ã‹ã‚Šã¾ã›ã‚“ã€‚SDZ_FIRESTORE_TOKEN / SDZ_STORAGE_SIGNING_TOKEN ã¯æ‰‹å‹•ã§è¨­å®šã—ã¦ãã ã•ã„"
    return 0
  fi

  info "gcloud access token ã‚’å–å¾—ä¸­..."
  local token
  token=$(gcloud auth print-access-token 2>/dev/null) || {
    warn "gcloud auth print-access-token ã«å¤±æ•—ã—ã¾ã—ãŸã€‚gcloud auth login ã‚’å®Ÿè¡Œã—ã¦ãã ã•ã„"
    return 0
  }

  # sed ã§ REPLACE_BY_SCRIPT ã‚’å®Ÿéš›ã®ãƒˆãƒ¼ã‚¯ãƒ³ã«ç½®æ›
  if [[ "$(uname)" == "Darwin" ]]; then
    sed -i '' "s|SDZ_FIRESTORE_TOKEN=REPLACE_BY_SCRIPT|SDZ_FIRESTORE_TOKEN=${token}|" "${env_file}"
    sed -i '' "s|SDZ_STORAGE_SIGNING_TOKEN=REPLACE_BY_SCRIPT|SDZ_STORAGE_SIGNING_TOKEN=${token}|" "${env_file}"
  else
    sed -i "s|SDZ_FIRESTORE_TOKEN=REPLACE_BY_SCRIPT|SDZ_FIRESTORE_TOKEN=${token}|" "${env_file}"
    sed -i "s|SDZ_STORAGE_SIGNING_TOKEN=REPLACE_BY_SCRIPT|SDZ_STORAGE_SIGNING_TOKEN=${token}|" "${env_file}"
  fi
  info "å‹•çš„ãƒˆãƒ¼ã‚¯ãƒ³ã‚’ .env ã«æ³¨å…¥ã—ã¾ã—ãŸ"
}

# ãƒ¡ã‚¤ãƒ³å‡¦ç†
main() {
  echo "=== spot-diggz ã‚·ãƒ¼ã‚¯ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆå–å¾— ==="
  echo ""

  check_op_cli
  check_op_auth
  check_vault "sdz-dev"

  echo ""

  # API ç’°å¢ƒå¤‰æ•°
  inject_env \
    "${PROJECT_ROOT}/web/api/.env.tpl" \
    "${PROJECT_ROOT}/web/api/.env" \
    "API"

  # å‹•çš„ãƒˆãƒ¼ã‚¯ãƒ³ã®æ³¨å…¥
  inject_dynamic_tokens "${PROJECT_ROOT}/web/api/.env"

  echo ""

  # UI ç’°å¢ƒå¤‰æ•°
  inject_env \
    "${PROJECT_ROOT}/web/ui/.env.tpl" \
    "${PROJECT_ROOT}/web/ui/.env.local" \
    "UI"

  echo ""
  info "å…¨ã¦ã®ç’°å¢ƒå¤‰æ•°ãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚¤ãƒ«ã‚’ç”Ÿæˆã—ã¾ã—ãŸ"
  echo ""
  echo "æ¬¡ã®ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒƒãƒ—:"
  echo "  cd web/api && cargo run      # API ã‚µãƒ¼ãƒãƒ¼èµ·å‹•"
  echo "  cd web/ui && npm run dev     # UI é–‹ç™ºã‚µãƒ¼ãƒãƒ¼èµ·å‹•"
}

main "$@"

# CLAUDE.md

## ãƒ—ãƒ­ã‚¸ã‚§ã‚¯ãƒˆæ¦‚è¦

spot-diggz: ã‚¹ã‚±ãƒ¼ãƒˆã‚¹ãƒãƒƒãƒˆæ¤œç´¢ãƒ»ã‚·ã‚§ã‚¢ã‚¢ãƒ—ãƒªï¼ˆæ—§SkateSpotSearchã®ãƒªãƒ—ãƒ¬ã‚¤ã‚¹ï¼‰

- ãƒãƒƒã‚¯ã‚¨ãƒ³ãƒ‰: Rustï¼ˆã‚¹ã‚¯ãƒ©ãƒƒãƒå®Ÿè£…ã€ãƒ•ãƒ¬ãƒ¼ãƒ ãƒ¯ãƒ¼ã‚¯éä½¿ç”¨ï¼‰ â†’ `web/api/`
- ãƒ•ãƒ­ãƒ³ãƒˆã‚¨ãƒ³ãƒ‰: React + TypeScript â†’ `web/ui/`
- ã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒ•ãƒ©: GCP (Cloud Run, Firestore) + Terraform â†’ `web/resources/`
- ãƒ¢ãƒã‚¤ãƒ«: iOS (`iOS/`), Android (`android/`) â€»äºˆå®š

## ãƒ“ãƒ«ãƒ‰ãƒ»ãƒ†ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ»Lintã‚³ãƒãƒ³ãƒ‰

### Rust API (`web/api/`)


### React UI (`web/ui/`)


### Terraform (`web/resources/`)

```bash

```

content.content:
Web search results for query: "1Password CLI op:// URI vault item section field structure"

Links: [{"title":"1Password CLI reference | 1Password Developer","url":"https://developer.1password.com/docs/cli/reference/"},{"title":"Create items with 1Password CLI | 1Password Developer","url":"https://developer.1password.com/docs/cli/item-create/"},{"title":"item | 1Password CLI | 1Password Developer","url":"https://developer.1password.com/docs/cli/reference/management-commands/item/"},{"title":"vault | 1Password CLI | 1Password Developer","url":"https://developer.1password.com/docs/cli/reference/management-commands/vault/"},{"title":"onepasswordItemFields - chezmoi","url":"https://www.chezmoi.io/reference/templates/1password-functions/onepasswordItemFields/"},{"title":"Using 1password-cli to avoid hardcoded secrets in your terminal profile - Nando Vieira","url":"https://nandovieira.com/using-1password-cli-to-avoid-hardcoded-secrets-in-your-terminal-profile"},{"title":"Use secret references with 1Password CLI | 1Password Developer","url":"https://developer.1password.com/docs/cli/secret-references/"},{"title":"Managing Secrets with 1Password CLI | Chainlink Documentation","url":"https://docs.chain.link/cre/guides/workflow/secrets/managing-secrets-1password"},{"title":"1Password CLI Secret Reference Syntax | 1Password Developer","url":"https://developer.1password.com/docs/cli/secret-reference-syntax/"},{"title":"Using the 1Password CLI in a script â€“ Rob Allen","url":"https://akrabat.com/using-the-1password-cli-in-a-script/"}]

Based on the search results, here's the information about the 1Password CLI `op://` URI vault item section field structure:

## Secret Reference URI Structure

Secret reference URIs point to where a secret is saved in your 1Password account using the names (or unique identifiers) of the vault, item, section, and field where the information is stored.

The basic format for an `op://` URI is:
`op://<vault-name>/<item-name>/<field-name>`

## URI with Section

To create a secret reference that refers to a field within a section, such as the PagerDuty email field within the Admin section, use the format with the section name included. Based on the search results, when a field is within a section, the URI structure becomes:

`op://<vault-name>/<item-name>/<section-name>/<field-name>`

## Examples from the Data

The search results show a real example where a field reference appears as `op://dev/main/dev/SOME_API_KEY` (where "dev" is both the vault and section name, "main" is the item, and "SOME_API_KEY" is the field).

## Key Points

- Secret references are case-insensitive and if a secret reference includes an unsupported character, that part must be referred to by its unique identifier (ID) instead of its name.
- If a secret reference includes whitespace, enclose the secret reference in quotation marks.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Here are the web search results for 1Password vault design pattern best practices, secrets management, and op CLI:

## Key Best Practices

Use dedicated vaults with service accounts that are properly scoped for secrets management use cases. Do not grant access to more vaults than needed, applying the principle of least privilege.

Service accounts should be used to follow the principle of least privilege, as they support restricting 1Password CLI to specific vaults, so processes can only access items required for a given purpose.

## 1Password CLI (op) Core Commands

You can use op read to write secrets to stdout or to a file, op run to pass secrets as environment variables to a process, and op inject to inject secrets into configuration files or scripts.

op run scans environment variables for secret references, loads the corresponding values from 1Password, then runs the provided command in a subprocess with the secrets made available as environment variables for the duration of the subprocess.

## Secret References Pattern

A secret reference URI includes the names (or unique identifiers) of the vault, item, section, and field where a secret is stored in your 1Password account. The basic format is op://vault/item/[section/]field.

## Development Workflow

The 1Password CLI brings secrets management directly into your development workflow, with op run allowing you to inject secrets as environment variables without ever exposing them in your shell history or process list.

1Password provides programmatic management of vault items and allows developers to build AI workflows that securely read, write, share, and rotate secrets at runtime through the 1Password SDK.

Based on the search results, I found relevant guidance on 1Password vault organization for developers managing multiple environments.

## Vault Per Environment Approach

For managing different environments, the best practice is to organize project secrets into different vaults for each environment, with each item's fields structured in the same way (for example: dev/mysql/password and prod/mysql/password).

You can include an externally set variable ($VARIABLE_NAME) in place of the vault name for each secret reference in your environment file, which can be set to dev or prod to load secrets from either the dev vault or the prod vault in 1Password.

## Multiple Environments Best Practice

If you have multiple environments (e.g. Development, Staging, and Production) you could create separate vaults that are shared with different teams in your Development and Deployment pipeline.

## Key Security Principles

It's both insecure and inconvenient to share your entire 1Password account with other developers. Instead, you should create and share 1Password vaults, which allow you to store multiple items in them and then choose who should be able to access them, keeping information on a need-to-know basis.

You can scope service account access to specific vaults and 1Password Environments so that processes in your authorized terminal session can only access secrets required for a given purpose.

The search results focus primarily on vault organization and environment-based separation rather than discussing tags and sections in detail, but the clear recommendation is to use **separate vaults per environment** for better access control and security management in development workflows.

# 1Password CLI Best Practices

Based on the documentation, here are the key best practices for 1Password CLI usage:

## Software Maintenance
"Practice good software update hygiene and regularly update to the latest version of the 1Password CLI." Users can check for available updates using the `op update` command.

## Principle of Least Privilege
The documentation emphasizes implementing minimal access controls through Service Accounts. The recommendations include:

- Restrict CLI access to only the items necessary for specific tasks
- Use dedicated vaults with appropriately scoped service accounts for secrets management
- "Do not grant access to more vaults than needed"
- Reference the NIST principle of least privilege when structuring vault permissions

## Secure Item Creation
When generating items containing sensitive information using `op item create`, the guidance recommends leveraging JSON templates to safely input confidential values rather than inline methods.

---

**Note:** The provided documentation focuses primarily on these three core practices. It does not detail comprehensive vault organization structures, secret reference patterns, or advanced environment management strategies beyond these foundational recommendations.

content.content:
# 1Password CLI Secret References Documentation

## Overview

The documentation explains how to use **secret references** with 1Password CLI to securely load secrets into environment variables, configuration files, and scripts without exposing plaintext values.

## Secret Reference Structure

A secret reference URI contains:
- **Vault name/ID**
- **Item name/ID**
- **Section name/ID**
- **Field name/ID**

The exact syntax format details appear in the referenced [secret reference syntax guide](/docs/cli/secret-reference-syntax), though the full URI structure isn't fully detailed in this excerpt.

## Three Methods to Resolve References

### 1. `op read`
"You can use `op read` with a secret reference to print the secret to `stdout`."

Supports:
- Writing to files via `--out-file` flag
- Query parameters to retrieve field attributes (type, value, title, id, purpose, otp)
- SSH key formatting via `ssh-format=openssh` parameter

### 2. `op run`
"Wrap the command with `op run`" to pass secrets as environment variables to applications at runtime.

Key features:
- Scans environment variables for secret references
- Loads corresponding values from 1Password
- Masking enabled by default (use `--no-masking` to display)
- Works with environment files via `--env-file` flag

### 3. `op inject`
"Replace secret references in a script or file with the secrets they reference."

Capabilities:
- Reads from stdin or files (`--in-file`)
- Outputs to stdout or files (`--out-file`)
- Ideal for templated configuration files safe for version control

## Best Practices

The guide recommends using **1Password Service Accounts** to follow "the principle of least privilege," allowing processes to access only required items per purpose.

content.content:
# Loading Secrets into Environment Variables with 1Password CLI

## Overview

The `op run` command enables injecting secrets directly from 1Password as environment variables at runtime, avoiding hardcoded plaintext credentials. The documentation outlines three configuration approaches:

1. **1Password Environments (beta)** - Pre-configured sets of variables for specific workflows
2. **Secret references** - URI pointers to individual secrets stored in vaults
3. **Hybrid approach** - Combining both methods

## Multi-Environment Pattern

The documentation demonstrates a technique for managing secrets across different contexts (staging/production):

> "If you have different sets of secrets for different environments, like staging and production, you can check a single environment file into source control"

The pattern involves:
- Organizing secrets in separate vaults per environment (e.g., `dev/mysql/password`, `prod/mysql/password`)
- Using an externally-set variable placeholder within secret reference URIs
- Setting that variable at runtime to select the appropriate vault

For instance, an `app.env` file might contain `DATABASE_URL=op://dev/mysql/password` where `dev` is replaced via `$APP_ENV` variable expansion before execution.

## .env File Parsing Rules

Key behaviors include:
- Single-quoted values prevent variable substitution
- Double-quoted values allow `$VAR_NAME` or `${VAR_NAME}` replacement
- Special characters can be escaped with backslashes
- Empty lines and `#` comments are ignored
- UTF-8 character encoding required

## Command Execution

To prevent premature shell expansion of variables: "run the command to expand the variable in a subshell" to ensure `op run` processes secret references before variable interpolation occurs.

content.content:
# 1Password CLI Secret Reference Syntax Documentation

## Overview

Secret reference URIs point to secrets stored in 1Password accounts using vault, item, section, and field identifiers. They eliminate plaintext secrets in code and automatically reflect account updates.

## Basic URI Format

The syntax follows this pattern:
```
op://vault/item/section/field
op://vault/item/field
```

For file attachments, replace the field name with the filename.

## Supported Characters

"Secret references are case-insensitive and support the following characters: alphanumeric characters (a-z, A-Z, 0-9), `-`, `_`, `.` and the whitespace character"

When whitespace is included, enclose the reference in quotation marks. Unsupported characters require using the item's unique identifier (ID) instead of its name.

## Metadata Attributes

Use query parameters to retrieve additional information:

**Field Attributes:**
- `type`: The field's data type
- `value`: The field's content
- `id`: Unique identifier
- `purpose`: Designation (username, password, notes)
- `otp`: Generates one-time password codes

**File Attachment Attributes:**
- `content`: File data
- `size`: File size
- `name`: Filename

Example syntax: `op://vault/item/field?attr=otp`

## Variable Substitution

"If you use different sets of secrets in different environments, you can include variables within secret references and then set the variable to switch between secrets."

Example: `op://$APP_ENV/Credentials/password` where `$APP_ENV` resolves to `dev` or `prod`.

## Practical Examples

- Field in section: `op://Management/PagerDuty/Admin/email`
- Field without section: `op://dev/Stripe/publishable-key`
- SSH key format: `op://vault/item/private-key?ssh-format=openssh`

Based on the search results, here's what I found regarding 1Password service account vault scope, environment separation, and CI/CD secrets management patterns:

## Service Account Vault and Environment Scoping

You can scope service account access to specific vaults and 1Password Environments so that processes in your authorized terminal session can only access secrets required for a given purpose. You can choose which vaults and Environments the service account can access and its permissions in each vault.

## Environment Separation Patterns

1Password Environments (beta) allow you to create Environments in 1Password that contain all your environment variables for a specific workflow. You can share Environments with your team and create separate Environments for each project, application, or development context (like staging or production).

For multi-environment secrets, you must organize your project secrets in 1Password into different vaults for each environment, with each item's fields structured in the same way. For example: dev/mysql/password and prod/mysql/password.

## CI/CD Integration

With service accounts and the CLI, you can encrypt all of your secrets in 1Password and grant applications programmatic access, with the ability to control which vaults are accessible and which actions the service account can perform. This helps reduce secrets sprawl across your organization by securing your secrets in a single place and eliminating hard-coded secrets.

This integration allows you to load secrets from 1Password directly into your GitHub Actions runner, providing an easy way to manage secrets in a single source of truth and eliminating the risk of exposing plaintext secrets in code.

## Important Limitations

Service account permissions, vault access, and Environment access are immutable. If you want to grant a service account access to additional vaults or Environments, change the permissions it has in the vaults it can access, or change its ability to create new vaults, you'll need to create a new service account with the appropriate permissions and access.

I found comprehensive information about using the 1Password CLI with `op run`, environment files, and managing multiple environments with vault separation. Here's what I found:

## Multiple Environments with Vault Separation

To organize project secrets for different environments, you must organize your secrets in 1Password into different vaults for each environment, with each item's fields structured in the same way. For example: dev/mysql/password and prod/mysql/password.

## Using op run with Environment Files

op run can scan environment variables and files for secret references, then load the provided command with the referenced secrets made available as environment variables.

To use an environment file with op run, specify the path to the environment file using the --env-file flag.

## Real-World Example: Switching Between Environments

If you have different sets of secrets for different environments, like staging and production, you can check a single environment file into source control and include a variable within the secret references to represent the context. You can then set the variable to the appropriate context when you pass the file to op run.

You can include an externally set variable ($VARIABLE_NAME) in place of the vault name for each secret reference in your environment file. It can be set to dev or prod to load secrets from either the dev vault or the prod vault in 1Password.

## Best Practice: Use Separate Vaults

Instead of creating separate entries in 1Password for each environment, you should create different Vaults. This approach allows you to manage access to each environment's secrets separately.

## Real-World Deployment Pattern

Depending on your deployment process, there's two options to consider when integrating the 1Password CLI: generating the .env directly on your production server(s) or generating the .env file on your local machine (or CI) and copying it to the production server(s). To access the 1Password vault on your production or staging servers, you'll need to create a 1Password service account. The op CLI and service account also need to be configured on your production or staging servers.

content.content:
# 1Password Service Accounts Summary

## Overview
Service accounts provide authentication for 1Password CLI without requiring individual user association. According to the documentation, "You control which vaults and Environments are accessible and which actions the service account can perform."

## Key Capabilities
- **Access Control**: Administrators can restrict vault and environment access per service account
- **Audit Trail**: Usage reports track what items each service account accesses
- **Quota**: Organizations can create up to 100 service accounts
- **Least Privilege**: Service accounts help implement security principles by compartmentalizing access

## Primary Use Cases
The documentation identifies six main applications:

1. **Web Services** - Provision accounts with secrets during deployments
2. **CI/CD Pipelines** - Automate secret injection without personal credentials
3. **Secrets Management** - Run automated scripts while avoiding SSO/MFA limitations
4. **Test Environments** - Create isolated testing setups alongside production Connect deployments
5. **Infrastructure Secrets** - Decouple infrastructure credentials from personal accounts
6. **Development Workflows** - Securely share secrets across teams

## Integration Options
Service accounts integrate with:
- 1Password CLI
- 1Password SDKs
- CI/CD platforms (via integrations)
- 1Password Environments for programmatic variable reading

The documentation emphasizes that service accounts suit "shared environments" where non-individual authentication is preferable.

content.content:
# Replacing .env Files with 1Password: Key Patterns

## Vault Organization Strategy

The recommended approach involves creating dedicated vaults for different environments and teams. As the article explains, "Vaults allow you to store multiple items in them and then choose who should be able to access them, keeping information on a need-to-know basis."

For example, you might establish separate vaults like "ENV_Demo_Secrets" for development work, with the ability to create additional vaults for staging and production environments shared with different team members.

## Secret Reference Examples

Rather than hardcoding values directly, the pattern replaces them with references:

- **Original approach**: `REDACTED`
- **New approach**: `APP_SECRET_TOKEN=op://ENV_Demo_Secrets/Blog 1 ENV App_Secret_Token/token`

This reference syntax points to a specific item within a designated vault and field.

## Four-Step Migration Strategy

1. **Install the VS Code Plugin** â€” Use the "Save in 1Password" action to automatically identify and migrate secrets
2. **Create Vaults** â€” Organize secrets by environment or team, moving items into appropriate vaults
3. **Implement SDKs** â€” Use 1Password SDKs to programmatically load secrets at application startup via Service Account authentication
4. **Rotate Keys** â€” Edit secrets directly in 1Password without modifying code

## Authentication Method

The approach uses Service Account tokens set as environment variables:

```
export OP_SERVICE_ACCOUNT_TOKEN=<your-service-account-token>
```

This enables secure, dynamic access without committing plaintext credentials to version control.

content.content:
# Securing CI/CD Pipelines with 1Password Service Accounts

## Core Security Approach

1Password Service Accounts enable programmatic access to infrastructure secrets without deploying additional infrastructure. The service enables teams to "encrypt all of your secrets in 1Password and grant applications programmatic access."

## GitHub Actions Integration

The implementation uses a straightforward configuration pattern:

1. **Create a service account** in 1Password
2. **Set the `OP_SERVICE_ACCOUNT_TOKEN`** environment variable in GitHub secrets
3. **Configure a workflow YAML** that specifies which secrets to load

Example workflow structure loads secrets directly into the runner while masking sensitive values in logs, preventing plaintext exposure in code repositories.

## Access Control & Vault Scoping

The service accounts framework provides granular control by allowing you to "control which vaults are accessible and which actions the service account can perform." This prevents over-privileged access and limits blast radius if credentials are compromised.

## Secret Organization Benefits

Rather than managing secrets across multiple locations, the service uses "a single place" for secret storage, which helps "reduce secrets sprawl across your organization by eliminating hard-coded secrets."

## Additional CI/CD Platforms

Beyond GitHub Actions, 1Password provides pre-built integrations for CircleCI and Jenkins, enabling consistent secret management across different pipeline tools.

Links: [{"title":"Organize & Control Password Access Using Shared Vaults | 1Password","url":"https://1password.com/resources/guides/create-and-manage-shared-vaults/"},{"title":"Create, share, and manage vaults in your team | 1Password Support","url":"https://support.1password.com/create-share-vaults-teams/"},{"title":"Use custom groups in 1Password Business | 1Password Support","url":"https://support.1password.com/custom-groups/"},{"title":"Step 3: Build your account structure | 1Password Community","url":"https://www.1password.community/kb/secured-success-quickstart/step-3-build-your-account-structure/164778"},{"title":"User management | 1Password","url":"https://1password.com/features/user-management/"},{"title":"Is it possible to share vault between organizations? â€” 1Password Community","url":"https://1password.community/discussion/145137/is-it-possible-to-share-vault-between-organizations"},{"title":"Company Vault Structures? â€” 1Password Community","url":"https://1password.community/discussion/96808/company-vault-structures"},{"title":"Advice on structuring vaults for a small business â€” 1Password Community","url":"https://1password.community/discussion/118195/advice-on-structuring-vaults-for-a-small-business"},{"title":"Object groups within a vault â€” 1Password Community","url":"https://1password.REDACTED"},{"title":"Issue: Account Owner Permissions & Vaults | 1Password Community","url":"https://www.1password.community/discussions/1password/issue-account-owner-permissions--vaults/151841"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about 1Password vault organization strategy recommendations:

## Core Organization Framework

Think of vaults as containers for data and groups as containers for people, with the way you combine them defining your overall account structure.

## Common Organizational Approaches

Common approaches include department-based vaults (Finance, Marketing, IT) and project-based vaults (Product Launch 2025, Vendor Onboarding). Additionally, many organizations organize their vault structure based on department, topic, location, or project.

## Default Vault Structure

Every 1Password account includes:
- Shared vault: Accessible to all team members by default, useful for company-wide resources like an office door code or shared Wi-Fi credentials.
- Employee vaults: Private to each team member, where every person has their own employee vault that no one else can see, ensuring team members have a secure place for work-related items specific to them.

## Management Strategies

You can choose centralized management where only admins and owners can create vaults to keep structure consistent and prevent "vault sprawl," or decentralized management where any team member can create vaults for flexibility but harder tracking.

## Using Groups with Vaults

Groups can separate workers by project, department, or location. With 1Password Business, custom groups make it easy to manage your team by project, department, or location.

## Scaling Strategy

Create one vault per department or project and one corresponding group, then assign each group to the right vaults - this centralized model makes it clear where data belongs and ensures admins retain visibility and control.

Good for AWS credentials.","url":"https://github.com/jagregory/1password-env"},{"title":"Using 1Password to Manage Environmental Variables","url":"https://nesin.io/blog/1password-environment-variables"},{"title":"1password-env/README.md at master Â· jagregory/1password-env","url":"https://github.com/jagregory/1password-env/blob/master/README.md"},{"title":"Managing Secrets with 1Password CLI | Chainlink Documentation","url":"https://docs.chain.link/cre/guides/workflow/secrets/managing-secrets-1password"},{"title":"1Password CLI reference | 1Password Developer","url":"https://developer.1password.com/docs/cli/reference/"},{"title":"Setting Env Vars From 1password - rossedman.io","url":"https://rossedman.io/blog/computers/setting-env-vars-from-1password/"}]

I found comprehensive information about 1Password CLI's `op run` command with `.env` files and secret references. Here are the key findings:

## Secret Reference Format

The secret references follow this format: export EXAMPLE="op://vault/item/[section/]field". This allows you to reference secrets stored in 1Password vaults without storing plaintext values.

## Practical Example with `.env` Files

For example, you might have something like: export ABC_BANK_USER_NAME="op://Personal/ABC_BANK/username" export ABC_BANK_PASSWORD="op://Personal/ABC_BANK/password", where the vault name is "Personal" and the item name is "ABC_BANK".

## Using `op run` Command

Use op run -- with the command for starting the application or script. 1Password will run the provided command in a subprocess with the secrets made available as environment variables for the duration of the process. The double dash (--) after op run is important! It tells the shell to pass all subsequent arguments to the command being run, rather than interpreting them as options to op run itself.

## Multi-Environment Setup

To organize project secrets into different environments, you must organize your secrets in 1Password into different vaults for each environment, with each item's fields structured the same way (for example: dev/mysql/password and prod/mysql/password). Then, include an externally set variable ($VARIABLE_NAME) in place of the vault name for each secret reference in your environment file.

## Version Control Safety

Once you've replaced all sensitive values with op:// references, you can safely commit your .env file to version control. The references themselves don't contain any sensitive information â€“ they're just pointers to your 1Password vault.

content.content:
# 1Password Account Structure Guidance

## Core Organizational Concepts

1Password accounts center on two interconnected elements: **vaults** (data containers) and **groups** (people containers). Understanding how these work together defines your account's overall structure.

## Vault Organization Patterns

The platform provides two default vaults:

- **Shared vault**: "Accessible to all team members by default" for company-wide resources
- **Employee vaults**: Private to each team member for work-related items specific to them

Beyond defaults, custom vaults should reflect your organization's needs:

- **Department-based**: Finance, Marketing, IT
- **Project-based**: "Product Launch 2025, Vendor Onboarding"

## Management Approach: Centralized vs. Decentralized

**Centralized management** restricts vault creation to admins and owners, preventing "vault sprawl" and maintaining consistency.

**Decentralized management** allows any team member to create vaults, offering flexibility but reducing visibility.

The recommendation: "Begin with centralized management, then expand permissions to trusted groups as your team grows."

## Group Structure

Built-in groups include Owners (full control), Administrators (powerful but no billing), Team Members (default access), and Security (domain-verified accounts only).

Custom groups can mirror departments, locations, or cross-functional teams.

## Key Recommendation

"Start simple. Create one vault per department or project, and one corresponding group. Then, assign each group to the right vaults." This approach maintains clarity while preserving admin control for future scaling.

content.content:
# 1Password CLI (`op`) Usage Guide

## Basic op run Syntax

The fundamental pattern for injecting secrets is straightforward:

```bash
op run -- <your-command>
```

The double dash (`--`) is criticalâ€”it prevents the shell from interpreting subsequent arguments as `op` options rather than passing them to your application.

## Vault Organization Patterns

Create environment-specific vaults rather than mixing all secrets together:

- **Development vault**: For local development credentials
- **Staging vault**: For staging environment access
- **Production vault**: For production secrets (with stricter access controls)

This separation provides clearer access control boundaries and reduces the blast radius if credentials are compromised.

## Secret Reference Examples

Replace raw values in `.env` files with vault pointers using this format:

```
op://vault-name/item-name-or-uuid/field-name
```

### Practical Examples

**API Credentials:**
```
AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID=op://development/AWS/username
AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY=op://development/AWS/credential
STRIPE_SECRET_KEY=op://development/stripe-api/password
```

**Database Connections:**
```
DATABASE_HOST=op://development/postgres-db/server
DATABASE_USER=op://development/postgres-db/username
DATABASE_PASSWORD=op://development/postgres-db/password
DATABASE_NAME=op://development/postgres-db/database
```

**Application Secrets:**
```
IRC_USERNAME=op://development/chatroom/username
IRC_PASSWORD=op://development/chatroom/password
```

## Item Type Selection in 1Password

Choose the appropriate item type when creating vault entries:

- **API Credential** â†’ Third-party service keys (fields: username, credential)
- **Password** â†’ First-party secrets like encryption keys (fields: username, password)
- **Database** â†’ Hosted database connections (fields: type, server, port, database, username, password)

## Development Workflow Integration

Update your startup scripts:

```bash
#!/bin/sh
op run -- swift run
```

Or for other frameworks:
```bash
op run -- npm start
op run -- python manage.py runserver
op run -- rails server
```

## Key Advantages

- **Onboarding**: New developers access secrets by joining the 1Password vault
- **Automatic updates**: Credential changes propagate immediately
- **Version history**: 1Password tracks all modifications
- **Secret masking**: Output redaction prevents accidental credential exposure in logs

## Important Considerations

**Performance**: Expect approximately 500-1000ms startup overhead per invocation.

**stdout/stderr redaction**: The masking feature modifies terminal behavior, which may cause issues with "certain terminal applications" or dev containers.

**Safe to commit**: `.env` files containing only `op://` references contain no sensitive data and can be committed to version controlâ€”override global `.gitignore` with:

```
!.env
```

## Secret Masking Control

By default, `op run` redacts secrets from output:

```
IRC_PASSWORD=<concealed by 1Password>
```

Disable masking if needed with the `--no-masking` flag (use cautiously).

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about 1Password's vault section versus separate items organization patterns:

## Key Organizational Concepts

Vaults are the actual storage locations for your data, providing fundamental organization and security boundaries, while collections are a way to create dynamic, personalized views of your existing data.

## Vaults vs. Tags

Vaults are for separating information, similar to filing cabinets, while tags are great for organizing information, comparable to folders within filing cabinets.

### Pros of Using Multiple Vaults:
- In terms of access control, vaults work well when organizing based upon who items need to be shared with.
- An archival vault can be created to archive items you no longer use and then excluded from All Vaults, so items won't be visible all the time but can always be accessed by selecting it in the vault menu.
- Using vaults to sort by purpose is useful because certain items may only be needed for particular tasks, and having them in separate vaults means you can exclude them from All Vaults so filling isn't cluttered most of the time.

### Cons/Limitations of Multiple Vaults:
- Having many vaults results in a massively long list of vaults, and nested vaults or folders within vaults would better organize data sets.
- Using tags across vaults requires less overhead than specifying both a vault and tag, and tags lack visual indicators like colored badges without inspecting an entry specifically.

### When to Use Tags Instead:
Tags are preferable for organizing items by role when you want real logins accessible at all times across multiple vaults, and when items are shared with teammates since moving them to separate vaults would disrupt the team's organizational system.

## Developer Workflow Considerations

The search results suggest that organizations typically organize vault structure based on department, topic, location, or project, though the optimal approach depends on access control needs versus simple organization preferences.

content.content:
# 1Password Vault Organization & Secrets Management

## Practical Vault Structure Examples

The article demonstrates organizing secrets by environment and application:

**Development Vault Example:**
```
Development/
â”œâ”€â”€ PostgreSQL/
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ password
â”œâ”€â”€ Stripe API/
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ credential
â”œâ”€â”€ AWS/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ access_key_id
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ secret_access_key
â””â”€â”€ GitHub/
    â””â”€â”€ token
```

**Production Vault Example:**
The guide references separate vaults for production: "Production/AWS/access_key_id" and "Production/AWS/secret_access_key" to maintain environment isolation.

## Op:// Reference Syntax Patterns

The canonical format shown is: `op://<vault>/<item>/<field>`

**Real-world examples from the guide:**
- `op://Development/PostgreSQL/password`
- `op://Development/Stripe API/credential`
- `op://Production/Database/password`

## Best Practice Recommendations

**Environment Separation:**
Run applications with environment-specific credential files to prevent cross-environment access: "Development should use development credentials, production should use production credentials."

**Reference-Based .env Files:**
Store only secret references (not values) in committed `.env` files, enabling safe version control while maintaining security.

**No Hardcoded Credentials:**
The guide emphasizes that "credentials leak into repositories, get shared in Slack channels, or end up in production configuration files" when hardcoded, making structured vault organization essential.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about 1Password CLI environments with the `op run` command:

## Overview

You can create separate Environments for each project, application, or development context (like staging or production).

## Using op run with Environments

You can use op run to pass environment variables stored in a 1Password Environment to an application or script at runtime, with the environment variables provisioned for the duration of the process.

## Handling Multiple Environments

If you have different sets of secrets for different environments, like staging and production, you can check a single environment file into source control and include a variable within the secret references to represent the context, then set the variable to the appropriate context when you pass the file to op run.

## Environment Precedence

If the same environment variable name exists in multiple environment files, the last environment file takes precedence. If the same environment variable name exists in multiple 1Password Environments, the last Environment specified takes precedence.

## Requirements

To use op run with 1Password Environments, you'll need to install the latest beta build of 1Password CLI, version 2.33.0-beta.02 or later.

You can use op run to pass environment variables stored in a 1Password Environment to an application or script at runtime, with the environment variables provisioned for the duration of the process.

## Handling Multiple Environments

If you have different sets of secrets for different environments, like staging and production, you can check a single environment file into source control and include a variable within the secret references to represent the context, then set the variable to the appropriate context when you pass the file to op run.

## Environment Precedence

If the same environment variable name exists in multiple environment files, the last environment file takes precedence. If the same environment variable name exists in multiple 1Password Environments, the last Environment specified takes precedence.

## Requirements

To use op run with 1Password Environments, you'll need to install the latest beta build of 1Password CLI, version 2.33.0-beta.02 or later.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about 1Password's developer environments feature for secrets management in 2025-2026:

## Key Features and Updates

1Password introduced Environments last year to give developers a dedicated place to manage application secrets. The feature has evolved significantly with several recent enhancements:

### Programmatic Access
You can now programmatically read 1Password Environments using 1Password SDKs or 1Password CLI. Secrets can be fetched programmatically from 1Password Environments at runtime through the CLI and SDKs, allowing tools to read secrets directly from 1Password as code runs.

### Environment Variable Management
You can create a locally mounted .env file to make your environment variables available during local development without writing plaintext secrets to disk. You can share Environments with your team members for easier collaboration and onboarding.

### Integration Capabilities
You can read environments and pass environment variables to applications and scripts using 1Password CLI or SDKs, and sync secrets from 1Password to AWS Secrets Manager.

### Desktop Authentication for SDKs
Following a four-month beta, SDK-based integrations can now authenticate programmatically through the desktop password manager using biometric or password prompts, bringing the same trusted, user-approved authentication flow developers rely on across 1Password's local developer tools.

### AI and CI/CD Support
You can use 1Password to securely provide credentials to AI agents over an end-to-end encrypted channel with human-in-the-loop approval.

Based on the search results, here's information about using the `op run --env` (or `--environments`) command with 1Password CLI:

## Basic Usage

You can use `op run` with the `--environments` flag and an Environment's ID to load variables from a 1Password Environment.

## Requirements

The `--environments` flag is available in the latest beta build of 1Password CLI, version 2.33.0-beta.02 or later.

## How It Works

You can use `op run` to pass environment variables stored in a 1Password Environment to an application or script at runtime. 1Password CLI runs the application or script in a subprocess with the environment variables stored in your 1Password Environment provisioned for the duration of the process.

## Getting Your Environment ID

To find an Environment's ID, open the 1Password app, navigate to Developer > View Environments > then select View environment > Manage environment > Copy environment ID.

## Basic Command Structure

The double dash (`--`) after `op run` is important. It tells the shell to pass all subsequent arguments to the command being run, rather than interpreting them as options to `op run` itself.

So a typical command would look like: `op run --environments YOUR_ENV_ID -- your-command-here`

Web search results for query: "1Password Connect Server Cloud Run sidecar container deployment"

Links: [{"title":"Get started with a 1Password Connect server | 1Password Developer","url":"https://developer.1password.com/docs/connect/get-started/"},{"title":"Cloud Run sidecars enable advanced multi-container patterns | Google Cloud Blog","url":"https://cloud.google.com/blog/products/serverless/cloud-run-now-supports-multi-container-deployments"},{"title":"Deploy 1Password SCIM Bridge on Azure Container Apps | 1Password Support","url":"https://support.1password.com/scim-deploy-azure/"},{"title":"Kubernetes Operator | 1Password Developer","url":"https://developer.1password.com/docs/k8s/operator/"},{"title":"1password/connect-sync - Docker Image","url":"https://hub.docker.com/r/1password/connect-sync"},{"title":"AWS ECS Fargate | 1Password Developer","url":"https://developer.1password.com/docs/connect/aws-ecs-fargate/"},{"title":"GitHub - 1Password/scim-examples: 1Password SCIM Bridge deployment examples","url":"https://github.com/1Password/scim-examples"},{"title":"connect/examples/kubernetes/README.md at main Â· 1Password/connect","url":"https://github.com/1Password/connect/blob/main/examples/kubernetes/README.md"},{"title":"Configure your Connect server | 1Password Developer","url":"https://developer.1password.com/docs/connect/server-configuration/"},{"title":"Connect concepts | 1Password Developer","url":"https://developer.1password.com/docs/connect/concepts/"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about 1Password Connect Server and Cloud Run sidecar container deployment:

## 1Password Connect Server Architecture

1Password Connect Server consists of two containers running in the same network: the Connect API container (1password/connect-api) and the Connect sync container (1password/connect-sync), both requiring a shared volume to store an encrypted copy of your data.

## Cloud Run Sidecars

A sidecar is an additional container that is running alongside your main container. To add proxies or sidecars alongside your main container, you can edit the YAML of your Cloud Run service using the command line or Cloud Console.

## Deployment Options

While the search results show that 1Password provides deployment documentation for various platforms including AWS Fargate and Kubernetes, I did not find specific documentation for deploying 1Password Connect Server as a sidecar container on Google Cloud Run. The 1Password examples focus on Docker Compose, Kubernetes deployments, and AWS Fargate.

If you're interested in this specific use case, you might want to consult:
- The official 1Password Connect documentation at developer.1password.com
- Google Cloud Run's sidecar configuration documentation
- Consider whether the two-container architecture of 1Password Connect aligns with your Cloud Run sidecar requirements


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's what I found regarding 1Password Service Account Cloud Run secrets integration:

## Overview

1Password Service Accounts enable you to automatically access your secrets in continuous integration environments. You can manage secrets with 1Password Service Accounts or 1Password Connect servers, with Service Accounts allowing you to automate secrets management in your applications and infrastructure without the need to deploy additional services.

## Recent Developments (2025-2026)

The most recent development is 1Password's first cloud integration for secrets syncing with AWS, with more cloud integrations coming soon. This was announced in May 2025 as part of 1Password environments (beta), a new, streamlined, and secure way to manage application secrets.

## Integration Capabilities

Users can use 1Password environments to scope secrets to a specific environment and sync them securely to AWS Secrets Manager, empowering teams to manage scoped environments independently with security controls already baked in.

While my search results show strong integration support for AWS Secrets Manager and GitHub Actions/CI-CD pipelines, there isn't specific documented information about a dedicated Cloud Run secrets integration in the search results. However, the general 1Password Service Account framework can be used with Cloud Run through standard authentication methods.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about 1Password SDK Rust support and languages available in 2025:

## 1Password SDK Languages

1Password has official SDKs for Python, Javascript and Go. While there is no official Rust SDK from 1Password, an unofficial Rust SDK was created as a wrapper around the core SDK library used in the Python SDK and is available on GitHub.

## Language Support for Type Synchronization

1Password maintains **Typeshare**, a tool for cross-language development. Typeshare converts Rust types into their equivalent forms in Swift, Go, Python, Kotlin, Scala and Typescript, which helps facilitate Rust-based backend development with multiple language frontends.

## Additional Rust Resources

There is a Rust SDK called connect-1password for 1Password Connect, built on tokio, hyper and hyper_rustls. Additionally, 1Password maintains passkey-rs, a Rust library for implementing passkeys.

So while Rust is heavily used internally at 1Password for core infrastructure, the official SDK ecosystem focuses on Python, JavaScript, and Go, with community/unofficial options available for Rust developers.

Links: [{"title":"Load secrets from 1Password into GitHub Actions | 1Password Developer","url":"https://developer.1password.com/docs/ci-cd/github-actions/"},{"title":"GitHub - 1Password/load-secrets-action: Load secrets from 1Password into your GitHub Actions jobs","url":"https://github.com/1Password/load-secrets-action"},{"title":"Load secrets from 1Password Â· Actions Â· GitHub Marketplace Â· GitHub","url":"https://github.com/marketplace/actions/load-secrets-from-1password"},{"title":"Securing CI/CD pipelines with 1Password Service Accounts | 1Password","url":"https://1password.com/blog/1password-service-accounts"},{"title":"Inject 1Password secrets into GHA Â· Actions Â· GitHub Marketplace Â· GitHub","url":"https://github.com/marketplace/actions/inject-1password-secrets-into-gha"},{"title":"GitHub - shyim/1password-load-secrets-action","url":"https://github.com/shyim/1password-load-secrets-action"},{"title":"Reading 1Passwords Secrets within GitHub Actions | 1Password Community","url":"https://1password.community/discussion/140420/reading-1passwords-secrets-within-github-actions"},{"title":"Reading attached files in \"load-secrets-action@v2\" GitHub Actions | 1Password Community","url":"https://www.1password.community/discussions/developers/reading-attached-files-in-load-secrets-actionv2-github-actions/87566"},{"title":"load-secrets-action/README.md at main Â· 1Password/load-secrets-action","url":"https://github.com/1Password/load-secrets-action/blob/main/README.md"},{"title":"Workflow runs Â· 1Password/load-secrets-action","url":"https://github.com/1Password/load-secrets-action/actions"}]

I found comprehensive information about the 1Password GitHub Action for loading secrets into CI/CD pipelines. Here's what the search revealed:

## Overview

load-secrets-action loads secrets from 1Password into GitHub Actions using Service Accounts or 1Password Connect. With the Load secrets from 1Password GitHub Action, you can securely load secrets from 1Password into GitHub Actions using secret references. Secret references sync automatically with 1Password and remove the risk of exposing plaintext secrets in code.

## How It Works

Specify in your workflow YAML file which secrets from 1Password should be loaded into your job, and the action will make them available as environment variables for the next steps. Secret reference URIs point to where a secret is saved in your 1Password account using the names (or unique identifiers) of the vault, item, section, and field where the information is stored. Set an environment variable to a secret reference in your workflow YAML file, and the action will make the referenced secret available as the environment variable for the next steps.

## Authentication Methods

You can authenticate load-secrets-action with a 1Password Connect Server or a 1Password Service Account. Start by creating a service account in 1Password and then set the OP_SERVICE_ACCOUNT_TOKEN environment variable in GitHub to the service account token. This will give the GitHub Actions runner access to 1Password.

## Security Features

Similar to regular GitHub repository secrets, 1Password automatically masks sensitive fields that appear in GitHub Actions logs. If one of these values accidentally gets printed, it's replaced with ***.

The action is available on GitHub Marketplace and can be integrated into your CI/CD workflows to centralize secrets management and enhance security.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

content.content:
Web search results for query: "1Password vs GCP Secret Manager comparison Cloud Run cost"

Links: [{"title":"Google Cloud Secret Manager: Pricing, Reviews & Features 2026 | Cloud Tools","url":"https://cloud.toolsinfo.com/tool/google-cloud-secret-manager"},{"title":"A Comparison of Secrets Managers for GCP | ScaleSec","url":"https://scalesec.com/blog/a-comparison-of-secrets-managers-for-gcp/"},{"title":"Pricing | Secret Manager | Google Cloud","url":"https://cloud.google.com/secret-manager/pricing"},{"title":"My Top 12 Picks For The Best Secrets Management Tools In 2025","url":"https://kdpisda.in/my-top-12-picks-for-the-best-secrets-management-tools-in-2025/"},{"title":"Cloud Secret manager cost Comparison - breadNET Documentation","url":"https://documentation.breadnet.co.uk/cloud/secret-manager-comparison/"},{"title":"GCP Secret Manager: Pricing & Cost Optimization Best Practices","url":"https://www.economize.cloud/blog/secret-manager-cost-optimization/"},{"title":"Google Cloud Platform Setup optimization | 1Password Community","url":"https://www.1password.community/discussions/developers/google-cloud-platform-setup-optimization/74840"},{"title":"Secrets Management Tools: The Complete 2025 Guide | Pulumi Blog","url":"https://www.pulumi.com/blog/secrets-management-tools-guide/"},{"title":"1Password vs Google Cloud Secret Manager: Cloud Security Comparison","url":"https://6sense.com/tech/cloud-security/1password-vs-googlecloudsecretmanager"},{"title":"Google Cloud Secret Manager Alternatives & Competitors 2026","url":"https://www.strongdm.com/blog/alternatives-to-google-cloud-secret-manager"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about comparing 1Password with GCP Secret Manager, particularly in relation to Cloud Run and costs:

## Integration with Google Cloud

Google Cloud Secret Manager provides the most seamless experience for GCP users compared to third-party tools, but is not intended for use outside of the Google Cloud environment. GCP Secret Manager is useful for storing database credentials, API keys, and other runtime secrets for applications on Google Cloud, and for securing applications that use Google Cloud services like GKE and Cloud Run.

## Architectural Differences

The two solutions have different approaches. 1Password is known for its password manager and has extended into the developer world through an extension of its existing product, making adoption incredibly smooth since developers might already use it daily. 1Password allows developers to fetch secrets programmatically in CI/CD pipelines, applications, and infrastructure configurations through features like Service Accounts and the self-hosted 1Password Connect server.

## Cost Considerations

1Password Secrets Automation costs $8 per user per month with volume discounts available. For GCP Secret Manager, while specific pricing wasn't detailed in the results, cloud-native teams can leverage Google Secret Manager for seamless integration within their ecosystem, optimizing both cost and operational complexity.

## Recommendation

Cloud-native teams can leverage Google Secret Manager for seamless integration within their chosen ecosystem, while teams prioritizing rapid adoption and developer experience should consider 1Password Secrets Automation.

Web search results for query: "1Password Connect Server requirements self-hosted architecture two containers"

Links: [{"title":"1password/connect-sync - Docker Image","url":"https://hub.docker.com/r/1password/connect-sync"},{"title":"Configure your Connect server | 1Password Developer","url":"https://developer.1password.com/docs/connect/server-configuration/"},{"title":"Get started with a 1Password Connect server | 1Password Developer","url":"https://developer.1password.com/docs/connect/get-started/"},{"title":"1Password Connect | 1Password Developer","url":"https://developer.1password.com/docs/connect/"},{"title":"1password/connect-api - Docker Image","url":"https://hub.docker.com/r/1password/connect-api"},{"title":"Connect concepts | 1Password Developer","url":"https://developer.1password.com/docs/connect/concepts/"},{"title":"Deploy a 1Password Connect server on Northflank â€” Northflank","url":"https://northflank.com/guides/deploy-a-onepassword-connect-server-on-northflank"},{"title":"1Password Developer","url":"https://developer.1password.com/"},{"title":"1Password self-hosting | 1Password Community","url":"https://www.1password.community/discussions/1password/1password-self-hosting/134309"},{"title":"Self hosted instances? â€” 1Password Community","url":"https://1password.community/discussion/136186/self-hosted-instances"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about 1Password Connect Server requirements for self-hosted architecture:

## Container Architecture

1Password Connect Server consists of two containers running in the same network: the Connect API container (1password/connect-api) and the Connect sync container (1password/connect-sync). The connect-sync container keeps information available on the server updated with 1Password.com, while connect-api serves the Connect REST API.

## Storage Requirements

Both containers require a shared volume to store an encrypted copy of your data. The default location of the shared volume is /home/opuser/.op/data.

## Network Configuration

By default, the two containers (Connect API and Connect sync) automatically discover and connect to the shared bus. However, if automatic discovery isn't possible, you can manually configure the shared bus by assigning a static port using the OP_BUS_PORT environment variable, setting the OP_BUS_PEERS environment variable for the Connect API container to [hostname]:[bus port], and setting the OP_BUS_PEERS environment variable for the Connect sync container similarly.

## Authentication

When you create a Connect server, a credentials file named 1password-credentials.json is generated uniquely for that Connect server and contains all the information you need to deploy the Connect server.

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of 1Password's pricing plans for 2025-2026:

## Personal & Family Plans

Individual Plan: $2.99 USD per month when billed annually

Families Plan: $4.99 USD per month when billed annually

## Business Plans

### Teams Starter Pack
$19.95 USD per month for up to 10 users, billed annually

### Business Plan
List pricing is $7.99 per user per month when billed annually. This tier includes all Teams features plus enhanced security and compliance capabilities.

### Enterprise Plan
The Enterprise Plan is tailored for organizations with complex security needs and larger teams. Pricing is custom based on specific requirements.

## Key Features by Tier

- Team Starter Pack: Ideal for small teams, this plan supports up to 10 users at a flat monthly rate. Business Plan: Designed for larger organizations, it includes advanced features like integration with identity providers, usage reports, and administrative controls.

## Secrets Automation (Service Account)

Secrets Automation is an advanced capability for infrastructure teams. Availability depends on your plan tier; while it is a core feature for security teams, higher usage limits are typically tied to Business or Enterprise tiers.

## Trial & Billing Options

You can enjoy a 14-day free trial for 1Password family and team pricing. Annual contracts are priced lower than month-to-month. Multi-year commitments (2â€“3 years) often unlock additional discounts.

Web search results for query: "Cloud Run op CLI inject secrets startup 1password"

Links: [{"title":"Configure secrets for services | Cloud Run | Google Cloud Documentation","url":"https://docs.cloud.google.com/run/docs/configuring/services/secrets"},{"title":"Inject Secrets Into Config Files | 1Password Developer","url":"https://developer.1password.com/docs/cli/secrets-config-files/"},{"title":"Load secrets into scripts | 1Password Developer","url":"https://developer.1password.com/docs/cli/secrets-scripts/"},{"title":"Kubernetes Injector | 1Password Developer","url":"https://developer.1password.com/docs/k8s/injector/"},{"title":"Managing Secrets with 1Password CLI | Chainlink Documentation","url":"https://docs.chain.link/cre/guides/workflow/secrets/managing-secrets-1password"},{"title":"Load secrets into the environment | 1Password Developer","url":"https://developer.1password.com/docs/cli/secrets-environment-variables/"},{"title":"Configure secrets for jobs | Cloud Run | Google Cloud","url":"https://cloud.google.com/run/docs/configuring/jobs/secrets"},{"title":"inject | 1Password CLI | 1Password Developer","url":"https://developer.1password.com/docs/cli/reference/commands/inject/"},{"title":"Use secret references with 1Password CLI | 1Password Developer","url":"https://developer.1password.com/docs/cli/secret-references/"},{"title":"run | 1Password CLI | 1Password Developer","url":"https://developer.1password.com/docs/cli/reference/commands/run/"}]

Here are the search results for your query about Cloud Run, CLI, injecting secrets at startup, and 1Password:

## Key Findings:

**Cloud Run Secrets Configuration:**
Environment variables are resolved at instance startup time, so if you use this method, Google recommends that you pin the secret to a particular version instead of using latest as the version. You can make a secret accessible to your service using the Google Cloud console, the Google Cloud CLI, or a YAML file when you deploy a new service or update an existing service, and deploy a revision.

**1Password CLI Secret Injection Methods:**
With 1Password CLI, you can use secret references to securely load information saved in 1Password into environment variables, configuration files, and scripts without exposing any secrets in plaintext. To replace secret references with the secrets they refer to at runtime, use op read, op run, or op inject.

**Using op inject:**
Inject secrets into a file templated with secret references. You can use op inject to replace secret references in a script or file with the secrets they reference. By default, op inject accepts input on stdin and outputs on stdout. You can use the --in-file flag (or -i) to read the input from a file instead, and the --out-file flag (or -o) to specify where the ouput should be written.

**Using op run:**
Use op run to securely load project secrets from 1Password, then run a provided command in a subprocess with the secrets made available as environment variables only for the duration of the subprocess.

These tools can be combined to inject 1Password secrets into Cloud Run services at startup time using the gcloud CLI.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's the current GCP Secret Manager pricing for secret version access in 2025:

## Access Operations Pricing

Access operations (reading secret values) are charged at $0.01 per 10,000 operations. This is the pricing specifically for accessing secret versions.

## Free Tier

The first 10,000 access operations per month per project are free, so you only start incurring charges once you exceed this threshold.

## Active Secret Versions Storage

In addition to access costs, Secret Manager charges a flat $0.06 per month for each active secret version. GCP provides 6 free active secret versions per month, so you'll only begin incurring charges after exceeding this free tier.

## Example

If your application reads secrets 100,000 times in a month, you would pay $0.09 that month for access operations (100,000 â€“ 10,000 free tier = 90,000 charged access operations).

The pricing is straightforward: you pay for the active secret versions you store and for each access operation beyond the free tier allowance.

Web search results for query: "1Password SDK official languages Go Python JavaScript Node.js service accounts"

Links: [{"title":"1Password SDKs | 1Password Developer","url":"https://developer.1password.com/docs/sdks/"},{"title":"Tutorial: Get started with 1Password SDKs and 1Password Service Accounts | 1Password Developer","url":"https://developer.1password.com/docs/sdks/setup-tutorial/"},{"title":"GitHub - 1Password/onepassword-sdk-js: The official JavaScript SDK for 1Password","url":"https://github.com/1Password/onepassword-sdk-js"},{"title":"1Password SDKs are now available in beta | 1Password","url":"https://blog.1password.com/sdk-beta/"},{"title":"1Password Developer â€“ Secure Your Secrets | 1Password","url":"https://1password.com/developer-security"},{"title":"1Password Connect | 1Password Developer","url":"https://developer.1password.com/docs/connect/"},{"title":"1Password SDKs are now available in beta | 1Password Blog","url":"https://blog.1password.com/sdk-beta/?utm_ref=social"},{"title":"1Password Releases","url":"https://releases.1password.com/developers/sdks/"},{"title":"Supercharge your workflow: Use 1Password service accounts and SDKs to secure agentic AI access | 1Password","url":"https://1password.com/blog/service-accounts-sdks-agentic-ai"},{"title":"GitHub - 1Password/connect-sdk-js: Node SDK for 1Password Connect","url":"https://github.com/1Password/connect-sdk-js"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about 1Password SDK official languages, Go, Python, JavaScript/Node.js, and service accounts:

## Official Languages

1Password SDKs allow you to build integrations that programmatically interact with 1Password using Go, JavaScript, or Python. Note that the official SDKs do not include a separate Node.js SDK, but rather the JavaScript SDK is used for Node.js projects.

## Service Accounts

1Password SDKs support automated access for building integrations that authenticate with service account tokens for least-privilege access and automated environments. Service account authentication is best for automated access and limiting your integration to least privilege access, and requires creating a service account and giving it appropriate permissions in the vaults where items are saved.

## SDK Features

With 1Password SDKs, you can secure your applications by loading secrets into your code with secret references or reading environment variables from 1Password Environments. Additionally, you can programmatically manage items in your 1Password account, securely share items, and manage your team's vaults and the permissions groups have in them.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about 1Password syncing secrets to GCP Secret Manager:

## Key Findings:

**Direct 1Password-to-GCP Integration:**
While 1Password has launched a secrets syncing integration with AWS Secrets Manager, AWS Secrets Manager is the first destination they're syncing to. This suggests that a direct 1Password-to-GCP Secret Manager integration may not yet be available as of February 2026.

**Alternative Approaches:**

1. **Using Sanctuary Tool:** A tool named sanctuary is used to synchronise secrets, and it can synchronise a secret from 1password to a Google Secret Manager secret. This tool ships as part of the logan tool since it is usually used as part of a deployment to Google Cloud.

2. **1Password Secrets Automation:** Service accounts allow you to automate secrets management in your applications and infrastructure without the need to deploy additional services, and work well for shared environments by providing an authentication method for 1Password CLI.

3. **Connect Servers:** Self-hosted Connect servers allow for more control, scalability, and reduced dependency on the availability of the 1Password API.

The search results show that while 1Password offers robust secrets automation capabilities, the native integration with GCP Secret Manager may not be as direct as the newer AWS Secrets Manager integration.

Based on the web search results, here's information about 1Password's pricing plans for Teams Starter, Business, and related offerings:

## Available Plans and Pricing

1Password offers three plans designed for different company sizes: Teams Starter, Business, and Enterprise.

**Teams Starter Pack:**
The Teams Starter Pack is perfect for smaller businesses and protects up to 10 team members for $19.95 USD per month.

**Business Plan:**
The Business plan is $7.99/month per person and adds additional advantages, such as event reporting, custom policies, and advanced analytics, providing you with more control over your team's online safety. It encompasses everything in the Teams Starter Pack but adds crucial enterprise-level features. Think integrations with major identity providers like Okta, Entra ID, OneLogin, and Duo.

## Key Features

Each option provides end-to-end encrypted storage for shared accounts, secure credential sharing, and built-in security alerts to help organizations protect sensitive data.

## Additional Options

You can buy 1Password Business through AWS, which simplifies procurement and billing, offering a scalable and flexible deployment. This can be particularly appealing for organizations already heavily invested in the AWS ecosystem.

content.content:
1â†’#!/usr/bin/env bash
     2â†’set -euo pipefail
     3â†’
     4â†’api_url="${SDZ_API_URL:-http://localhost:8080}"
     5â†’
     6â†’if [[ -z "${SDZ_ID_TOKEN:-}" ]]; then
     7â†’  echo "SDZ_ID_TOKEN is required (Firebase ID token for Authorization header)." >&2
     8â†’  exit 1
     9â†’fi
    10â†’
    11â†’spot_name="smoke-$(uuidgen | tr '[:upper:]' '[:lower:]')"
    12â†’payload=$(cat <<EOF
    13â†’{
    14â†’  "name": "${spot_name}",
    15â†’  "description": "smoke test",
    16â†’  "location": { "lat": 35.6812, "lng": 139.7671 },
    17â†’  "tags": ["smoke"],
    18â†’  "images": []
    19â†’}
    20â†’EOF
    21â†’)
    22â†’
    23â†’echo "POST /sdz/spots"
    24â†’create_response=$(curl -sS -X POST "${api_url}/sdz/spots" \
    25â†’  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
    26â†’  -H "Authorization: Bearer ${SDZ_ID_TOKEN}" \
    27â†’  -H "X-SDZ-Client: ios" \
    28â†’  -d "${payload}")
    29â†’
    30â†’spot_id=$(echo "${create_response}" | jq -r '.spotId')
    31â†’if [[ -z "${spot_id}" || "${spot_id}" == "null" ]]; then
    32â†’  echo "failed to create spot: ${create_response}" >&2
    33â†’  exit 1
    34â†’fi
    35â†’
    36â†’echo "GET /sdz/spots/${spot_id}"
    37â†’curl -sS "${api_url}/sdz/spots/${spot_id}" | jq .
    38â†’
    39â†’echo "GET /sdz/spots"
    40â†’curl -sS "${api_url}/sdz/spots" | jq '.[0:3]'
    41â†’

1â†’#!/usr/bin/env bash

     7â†’SCRIPT_DIR="$(cd "$(dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}")" && pwd)"

    10â†’# è‰²ä»˜ãå‡ºåŠ›
    11â†’RED='\033[0;31m'

    20â†’# op CLI ã®å­˜åœ¨ãƒã‚§ãƒƒã‚¯

    33â†’# op CLI ã®èªè¨¼ãƒã‚§ãƒƒã‚¯

    49â†’check_vault() {

    63â†’inject_env() {
    64â†’  local tpl_file="$1"

    66â†’  local label="$3"
    67â†’
    68â†’  if [[ ! -f "${tpl_file}" ]]; then
    69â†’    error "ãƒ†ãƒ³ãƒ—ãƒ¬ãƒ¼ãƒˆãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚¤ãƒ«ãŒè¦‹ã¤ã‹ã‚Šã¾ã›ã‚“: ${tpl_file}"

    77â†’
    78â†’# å‹•çš„ãƒˆãƒ¼ã‚¯ãƒ³ã®å–å¾—ãƒ»è¿½è¨˜
    79â†’inject_dynamic_tokens() {

    98â†’  else
    99â†’    sed -i "s|SDZ_FIRESTORE_TOKEN=REPLACE_BY_SCRIPT|SDZ_FIRESTORE_TOKEN=${token}|" "${env_file}"
   100â†’    sed -i "s|SDZ_STORAGE_SIGNING_TOKEN=REPLACE_BY_SCRIPT|SDZ_STORAGE_SIGNING_TOKEN=${token}|" "${env_file}"
   101â†’  fi

   103â†’}

   106â†’main() {

   114â†’  echo ""

   133â†’  echo ""

   135â†’  echo ""

1â†’FROM rust:1.93-bookworm AS builder
     2â†’
     3â†’WORKDIR /app
     4â†’COPY Cargo.toml Cargo.lock ./
     5â†’COPY src ./src
     6â†’
     7â†’ENV CARGO_REGISTRIES_CRATES_IO_PROTOCOL=sparse
     8â†’ENV RUST_MIN_STACK=16777216
     9â†’ENV CARGO_BUILD_JOBS=1
    10â†’RUN cargo build --release
    11â†’
    12â†’FROM debian:bookworm-slim
    13â†’
    14â†’RUN apt-get update \
    15â†’  && apt-get install -y --no-install-recommends ca-certificates libssl3 \
    16â†’  && rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/*
    17â†’
    18â†’RUN useradd -r -u 10001 sdz
    19â†’
    20â†’WORKDIR /app
    21â†’COPY --from=builder /app/target/release/sdz_api /usr/local/bin/sdz_api
    22â†’
    23â†’ENV RUST_LOG=info,sdz_api=debug
    24â†’EXPOSE 8080
    25â†’USER sdz
    26â†’
    27â†’CMD ["sdz_api"]
    28â†’

Based on the search results, here's what I found regarding 1Password Connect Server pricing and the Business plan:

## 1Password Connect Server Pricing

Unlimited Connect usage is included! This means that 1Password Connect Server comes at no additional costâ€”it's included with your 1Password subscription.

## 1Password Business Plan Pricing

The 1Password Business plan is priced at $7.99 per user, per month, billed annually. It encompasses everything in the Teams Starter Pack but adds crucial enterprise-level features including integrations with major identity providers like Okta, Entra ID, OneLogin, and Duo, advanced role-based vault sharing and permissions, and comprehensive Watchtower alerts.

## Self-Hosted Deployment

Regarding self-hosted options, 1Password does not offer a self-hosted option for its standard password management plans. However, 1Password Enterprise includes advanced deployment options (private cloud configurations) for organizations with specific compliance or data residency requirements.
