I found information about 1Password's Teams Starter and Business plans. However, I notice the search results don't contain specific information about 1Password "Service Accounts" as a distinct feature or plan tier. Let me clarify what I found:

## 1Password Teams Starter vs Business Plan Comparison

**Teams Starter Plan:**
- Secure a team of up to 10 for a flat monthly price
- Comes at $19.95/month and includes essential features like secure password sharing and email support
- Includes role-based vault sharing and permissions

**Business Plan:**
- Combines comprehensive protection with granular controls
- Includes advanced security, reporting, and support options
- Unlocking 1Password with SSO is only available with 1Password Business, not 1Password Teams, and additional exclusive features include free 1Password Families accounts for your users
- Offers analytics and usage reports including audit trail, plus your team gains 5GB document storage per person (up from 1GB on the Teams plan)

**Key Feature Differences:**
Some security tools and features only exist in the Business tier, making it more difficult to manage and troubleshoot with Teams plans

Regarding "Service Accounts" specifically, the search results do not contain information about a distinct 1Password Service Account product or plan tier. If you're looking for information about a specific Service Account feature, you may want to check 1Password's official documentation or contact their sales team directly.

content.content:
1â†’name: ğŸš€ spot-diggz CI/CD Pipeline
     2â†’
     3â†’on:
     4â†’  push:
     5â†’    branches: [main, develop, feature/*]
     6â†’  pull_request:
     7â†’    branches: [main, develop]
     8â†’  workflow_dispatch:
     9â†’
    10â†’env:
    11â†’  CARGO_TERM_COLOR: always
    12â†’  RUST_BACKTRACE: 1
    13â†’  SDZ_ENABLE_STAGING_DEPLOY: "false"
    14â†’
    15â†’jobs:
    16â†’  # Rust API ã®ãƒ†ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ»ãƒ“ãƒ«ãƒ‰
    17â†’  rust-ci:
    18â†’    name: ğŸ¦€ Rust API CI
    19â†’    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    20â†’    defaults:
    21â†’      run:
    22â†’        working-directory: ./web/api
    23â†’
    24â†’    steps:
    25â†’      - name: ğŸ“¥ Checkout repository
    26â†’        uses: actions/checkout@v4
    27â†’
    28â†’      - name: ğŸ¦€ Setup Rust
    29â†’        uses: dtolnay/rust-toolchain@stable
    30â†’        with:
    31â†’          components: rustfmt, clippy
    32â†’
    33â†’      - name: ğŸ“¦ Cache Cargo registry
    34â†’        uses: actions/cache@v4
    35â†’        with:
    36â†’          path: |
    37â†’            ~/.cargo/registry
    38â†’            ~/.cargo/git
    39â†’            web/api/target
    40â†’          key: ${{ runner.os }}-cargo-${{ hashFiles('**/Cargo.lock') }}
    41â†’          restore-keys: |
    42â†’            ${{ runner.os }}-cargo-
    43â†’
    44â†’      - name: ğŸ“‹ Check code formatting
    45â†’        run: cargo fmt -- --check
    46â†’
    47â†’      - name: ğŸ” Run Clippy lints
    48â†’        run: cargo clippy -- -D warnings
    49â†’
    50â†’      - name: ğŸ§ª Run unit tests
    51â†’        run: cargo test --verbose
    52â†’
    53â†’      - name: ğŸ—ï¸ Build release binary
    54â†’        run: cargo build --release --verbose
    55â†’
    56â†’  # React UI ã®ãƒ†ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ»ãƒ“ãƒ«ãƒ‰
    57â†’  react-ci:
    58â†’    name: âš›ï¸ React UI CI
    59â†’    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    60â†’    defaults:
    61â†’      run:
    62â†’        working-directory: ./web/ui
    63â†’
    64â†’    steps:
    65â†’      - name: ğŸ“¥ Checkout repository
    66â†’        uses: actions/checkout@v4
    67â†’
    68â†’      - name: ğŸ” Check lockfile exists
    69â†’        id: lockfile
    70â†’        run: |
    71â†’          if [ -f package-lock.json ]; then
    72â†’            echo "exists=yes" >> "$GITHUB_OUTPUT"
    73â†’          else
    74â†’            echo "package-lock.json not found, skipping React CI"
    75â†’            echo "exists=no" >> "$GITHUB_OUTPUT"
    76â†’          fi
    77â†’
    78â†’      - name: ğŸ“¦ Setup Node.js
    79â†’        if: steps.lockfile.outputs.exists == 'yes'
    80â†’        uses: actions/setup-node@v4
    81â†’        with:
    82â†’          node-version: '20'
    83â†’          cache: 'npm'
    84â†’          cache-dependency-path: web/ui/package-lock.json
    85â†’
    86â†’      - name: ğŸ“¦ Install dependencies
    87â†’        if: steps.lockfile.outputs.exists == 'yes'
    88â†’        run: npm ci
    89â†’
    90â†’      - name: ğŸ” Run ESLint
    91â†’        if: steps.lockfile.outputs.exists == 'yes'
    92â†’        run: npm run lint
    93â†’
    94â†’      - name: ğŸ“‹ Check TypeScript types
    95â†’        if: steps.lockfile.outputs.exists == 'yes'
    96â†’        run: npm run type-check
    97â†’
    98â†’      - name: ğŸ§ª Run unit tests
    99â†’        if: steps.lockfile.outputs.exists == 'yes'
   100â†’        run: npm test -- --coverage --watch=false
   101â†’
   102â†’      - name: ğŸ—ï¸ Build production bundle
   103â†’        if: steps.lockfile.outputs.exists == 'yes'
   104â†’        run: npm run build
   105â†’
   106â†’      - name: ğŸ“Š Upload coverage reports
   107â†’        if: steps.lockfile.outputs.exists == 'yes'
   108â†’        uses: codecov/codecov-action@v5
   109â†’        with:
   110â†’          directory: ./web/ui/coverage
   111â†’
   112â†’  # Terraform è¨­å®šæ¤œè¨¼
   113â†’  terraform-ci:
   114â†’    name: ğŸ—ï¸ Terraform CI
   115â†’    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
   116â†’    defaults:
   117â†’      run:
   118â†’        working-directory: ./web/resources
   119â†’
   120â†’    steps:
   121â†’      - name: ğŸ“¥ Checkout repository
   122â†’        uses: actions/checkout@v4
   123â†’
   124â†’      - name: ğŸ—ï¸ Setup Terraform
   125â†’        uses: hashicorp/setup-terraform@v3
   126â†’        with:
   127â†’          terraform_version: 1.6.6
   128â†’
   129â†’      - name: ğŸ“‹ Format check
   130â†’        run: terraform fmt -check -recursive
   131â†’
   132â†’      - name: ğŸ” Validate configuration
   133â†’        run: terraform init -backend=false && terraform validate
   134â†’
   135â†’      - name: ğŸ›¡ï¸ Security scan
   136â†’        uses: aquasecurity/tfsec-action@v1.0.3
   137â†’        with:
   138â†’          working_directory: web/resources
   139â†’
   140â†’  # Docker ã‚¤ãƒ¡ãƒ¼ã‚¸ãƒ“ãƒ«ãƒ‰
   141â†’  docker-ci:
   142â†’    name: ğŸ³ Docker CI
   143â†’    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
   144â†’    needs: [rust-ci, react-ci]
   145â†’    if: github.ref == 'refs/heads/main' || github.ref == 'refs/heads/develop'
   146â†’
   147â†’    steps:
   148â†’      - name: ğŸ“¥ Checkout repository
   149â†’        uses: actions/checkout@v4
   150â†’
   151â†’      - name: ğŸ³ Set up Docker Buildx
   152â†’        uses: docker/setup-buildx-action@v3
   153â†’
   154â†’      - name: ğŸ” Log in to GitHub Container Registry
   155â†’        uses: docker/login-action@v3
   156â†’        with:
   157â†’          registry: ghcr.io
   158â†’          username: ${{ github.actor }}
   159â†’          password: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
   160â†’
   161â†’      - name: ğŸ“ Extract metadata
   162â†’        id: meta
   163â†’        uses: docker/metadata-action@v5
   164â†’        with:
   165â†’          images: ghcr.io/${{ github.repository }}
   166â†’          tags: |
   167â†’            type=ref,event=branch
   168â†’            type=ref,event=pr
   169â†’            type=sha,prefix={{branch}}-
   170â†’
   171â†’      - name: ğŸ—ï¸ Build and push Docker image
   172â†’        uses: docker/build-push-action@v6
   173â†’        with:
   174â†’          context: .
   175â†’          file: .devcontainer/Dockerfile
   176â†’          push: true
   177â†’          tags: ${{ steps.meta.outputs.tags }}
   178â†’          labels: ${{ steps.meta.outputs.labels }}
   179â†’          cache-from: type=gha
   180â†’          cache-to: type=gha,mode=max
   181â†’
   182â†’  # ã‚»ã‚­ãƒ¥ãƒªãƒ†ã‚£ã‚¹ã‚­ãƒ£ãƒ³
   183â†’  security-scan:
   184â†’    name: ğŸ›¡ï¸ Security Scan
   185â†’    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
   186â†’
   187â†’    steps:
   188â†’      - name: ğŸ“¥ Checkout repository
   189â†’        uses: actions/checkout@v4
   190â†’
   191â†’      - name: ğŸ” Run Trivy vulnerability scanner
   192â†’        uses: aquasecurity/trivy-action@0.28.0
   193â†’        with:
   194â†’          scan-type: 'fs'
   195â†’          scan-ref: '.'
   196â†’          format: 'sarif'
   197â†’          output: 'trivy-results.sarif'
   198â†’
   199â†’      - name: ğŸ“Š Upload Trivy scan results
   200â†’        uses: github/codeql-action/upload-sarif@v3
   201â†’        if: always()
   202â†’        with:
   203â†’          sarif_file: 'trivy-results.sarif'
   204â†’
   205â†’  # ä¾å­˜é–¢ä¿‚ãƒã‚§ãƒƒã‚¯
   206â†’  dependency-review:
   207â†’    name: ğŸ“¦ Dependency Review
   208â†’    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
   209â†’    if: github.event_name == 'pull_request'
   210â†’
   211â†’    steps:
   212â†’      - name: ğŸ“¥ Checkout repository
   213â†’        uses: actions/checkout@v4
   214â†’
   215â†’      - name: ğŸ” Dependency Review
   216â†’        uses: actions/dependency-review-action@v4
   217â†’        with:
   218â†’          fail-on-severity: moderate
   219â†’
   220â†’  # é–‹ç™ºç’°å¢ƒãƒ‡ãƒ—ãƒ­ã‚¤ï¼ˆè‡ªå‹•ï¼‰
   221â†’  deploy-dev:
   222â†’    name: ğŸš€ Deploy to Development
   223â†’    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
   224â†’    needs: [rust-ci, react-ci, terraform-ci]
   225â†’    if: github.ref == 'refs/heads/develop' && github.event_name == 'push'
   226â†’    environment: development
   227â†’    permissions:
   228â†’      contents: read
   229â†’      id-token: write
   230â†’    env:
   231â†’      SDZ_GCP_PROJECT_ID: sdz-dev
   232â†’      SDZ_GCP_REGION: asia-northeast1
   233â†’      SDZ_STAGE: dev
   234â†’      SDZ_API_IMAGE: asia-northeast1-docker.pkg.dev/sdz-dev/sdz-dev-api/sdz-api:latest
   235â†’      SDZ_UI_BUCKET: sdz-dev-ui-bucket
   236â†’      SDZ_VITE_SDZ_API_URL: ${{ secrets.SDZ_DEV_API_URL }}
   237â†’      SDZ_VITE_FIREBASE_API_KEY: ${{ secrets.SDZ_DEV_FIREBASE_API_KEY }}
   238â†’      SDZ_VITE_FIREBASE_AUTH_DOMAIN: ${{ secrets.SDZ_DEV_FIREBASE_AUTH_DOMAIN }}
   239â†’      SDZ_VITE_FIREBASE_PROJECT_ID: ${{ secrets.SDZ_DEV_FIREBASE_PROJECT_ID }}
   240â†’      SDZ_WIF_PROVIDER: REDACTED
   241â†’      SDZ_WIF_SERVICE_ACCOUNT: sdz-dev-deploy-sa@sdz-dev.iam.gserviceaccount.com
   242â†’      SDZ_DEPLOY_SA_RESOURCE: projects/sdz-dev/serviceAccounts/sdz-dev-deploy-sa@sdz-dev.iam.gserviceaccount.com
   243â†’
   244â†’    steps:
   245â†’      - name: ğŸ“¥ Checkout repository
   246â†’        uses: actions/checkout@v4
   247â†’
   248â†’      - name: ğŸ” Authenticate to Google Cloud (WIF)
   249â†’        uses: google-github-actions/auth@v2
   250â†’        with:
   251â†’          workload_identity_provider: ${{ env.SDZ_WIF_PROVIDER }}
   252â†’          service_account: ${{ env.SDZ_WIF_SERVICE_ACCOUNT }}
   253â†’
   254â†’      - name: â˜ï¸ Set up Cloud SDK
   255â†’        uses: google-github-actions/setup-gcloud@v2
   256â†’
   257â†’      - name: ğŸ” Debug GCP auth context
   258â†’        run: |
   259â†’          echo "PROJECT=${SDZ_GCP_PROJECT_ID}"
   260â†’          gcloud auth list
   261â†’          gcloud config list
   262â†’          gsutil -D ls gs://${SDZ_GCP_PROJECT_ID}_cloudbuild || true
   263â†’          gsutil -D ls gs://${SDZ_GCP_PROJECT_ID}_cloudbuild/source || true
   264â†’
   265â†’      - name: ğŸ“¦ Trigger Cloud Build (API)
   266â†’        run: |
   267â†’          gcloud builds submit \
   268â†’            --project "${SDZ_GCP_PROJECT_ID}" \
   269â†’            --config web/resources/cloudbuild/cloudbuild_api.yaml \
   270â†’            --gcs-source-staging-dir=gs://${SDZ_GCP_PROJECT_ID}_cloudbuild/source \
   271â†’            --verbosity=debug \
   272â†’            --substitutions _PROJECT_ID="${SDZ_GCP_PROJECT_ID}",_REGION="${SDZ_GCP_REGION}",_STAGE="${SDZ_STAGE}",_API_IMAGE="${SDZ_API_IMAGE}",_DEPLOY_SA_RESOURCE="${SDZ_DEPLOY_SA_RESOURCE}"
   273â†’
   274â†’      - name: ğŸ“¦ Trigger Cloud Build (UI)
   275â†’        run: |
   276â†’          gcloud builds submit \
   277â†’            --project "${SDZ_GCP_PROJECT_ID}" \
   278â†’            --config web/resources/cloudbuild/cloudbuild_ui.yaml \
   279â†’            --gcs-source-staging-dir=gs://${SDZ_GCP_PROJECT_ID}_cloudbuild/source \
   280â†’            --verbosity=debug \
   281â†’            --substitutions _UI_BUCKET="${SDZ_UI_BUCKET}",_DEPLOY_SA_RESOURCE="${SDZ_DEPLOY_SA_RESOURCE}",_VITE_SDZ_API_URL="${SDZ_VITE_SDZ_API_URL}",_VITE_FIREBASE_API_KEY="${SDZ_VITE_FIREBASE_API_KEY}",_VITE_FIREBASE_AUTH_DOMAIN="${SDZ_VITE_FIREBASE_AUTH_DOMAIN}",_VITE_FIREBASE_PROJECT_ID="${SDZ_VITE_FIREBASE_PROJECT_ID}"
   282â†’
   283â†’  # ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ¼ã‚¸ãƒ³ã‚°ç’°å¢ƒãƒ‡ãƒ—ãƒ­ã‚¤ï¼ˆæ‰‹å‹•æ‰¿èªï¼‰
   284â†’  deploy-staging:

   309â†’  deploy-production:

Web search results for query: "Cloud Run sidecar multi-container shared volume configuration 2025"

Links: [{"title":"Create a Cloud Run service with a sidecar | Google Codelabs","url":"https://codelabs.developers.google.com/codelabs/create-cloud-run-service-sidebar-localhost-volume-mount"},{"title":"GCP Cloud Run sidecars with shared volume (Part 1) â€” PoC | by Adrian Arba | Medium","url":"https://medium.com/@adrianarba/gcp-cloud-run-sidecars-with-shared-volume-part-1-lessons-learned-5dec1d6fa009"},{"title":"Instrumenting a Python Cloud Run Container with Sidecar","url":"https://docs.datadoghq.com/serverless/google_cloud_run/containers/sidecar/python/"},{"title":"Cloud Run sidecars enable advanced multi-container patterns | Google Cloud Blog","url":"https://cloud.google.com/blog/products/serverless/cloud-run-now-supports-multi-container-deployments"},{"title":"How can I host multiple containers(sidecar) in cloud run - Serverless Applications - Google Developer forums","url":"https://discuss.google.dev/t/how-can-i-host-multiple-containers-sidecar-in-cloud-run/179565"},{"title":"Instrumenting a Node.js Cloud Run Container with Sidecar","url":"https://docs.datadoghq.com/serverless/google_cloud_run/containers/sidecar/nodejs/"},{"title":"Configure containers for services | Cloud Run | Google Cloud Documentation","url":"https://docs.cloud.google.com/run/docs/configuring/services/containers"},{"title":"GCP Cloud Run sidecars with shared volume (Part 2) â€” implementation | by Adrian Arba | Medium","url":"https://medium.com/@adrianarba/gcp-cloud-run-sidecars-with-shared-volume-part-2-implementation-0f1e4e4dbb75"},{"title":"Create jobs | Cloud Run | Google Cloud Documentation","url":"https://docs.cloud.google.com/run/docs/create-jobs"},{"title":"Deploying container images to Cloud Run | Google Cloud Documentation","url":"https://docs.cloud.google.com/run/docs/deploying"}]

I've completed the web search for "Cloud Run sidecar multi-container shared volume configuration 2025". Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Cloud Run services can have one main container for web ingress and one or more additional containers referred to as sidecars.

## Communication Methods

Multiple containers within a Cloud Run instance can communicate through the shared localhost network interface, and can also use in-memory volumes and mount them on the containers to share files.

## Shared Volume Configuration

All containers within an instance share the same network namespace and can also share files using an in-memory shared volume. To configure this, add the volume mount to every container in your application, choosing a path such as /shared-volume.

Sharing an in-memory volume mount between the ingress container and the sidecar is in public preview and requires using the gcloud beta command.

## Deployment Limits

You can deploy up to 10 containers per instance including the ingress container.

## Container Startup Order

You can specify container start up order within a deployment, and if you use healthchecks, Cloud Run follows the container startup order and inspects the health of each container before starting the next one.

## Key Considerations

When creating an in-memory volume, it's recommended to specify a size limit, as writes will fail with an out-of-memory error if the volume reaches its limit.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about the `connect-1password` Rust crate:

## Overview

The 1Password Connect Rust SDK provides your Rust applications access to the 1Password Connect API hosted on your infrastructure and leverage the power of 1Password Secrets Automation. The library can be used by Rust applications, tools, and other automations to access and manage items in 1Password Vaults.

## Key Details

- **Availability**: The crate is available on [crates.io](https://crates.io/crates/connect-1password)
- **Latest Version**: Version 2.0.1
- **Status**: This Rust crate has been created solely by one individual and so far is not "officially" supported by the awesome folk at 1Password.

## Technical Implementation

The implementation is based on tokio, hyper and hyper_rustls by default, and hyper can be replaced using the HTTPClient interface.

## API Coverage

The current goal is to cover all existing API end-points (in progress).

## Documentation

Documentation and examples are available on [docs.rs](https://docs.rs/connect-1password), with setup instructions involving Docker and environment configuration for the 1Password Connect API server.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Cloud Run cold start latency and sidecar containers:

## Cold Start Components

Cold starts in Cloud Run include container scheduling (~200ms), image pull (~500-2000ms depending on image size), container start (~200ms), and application initialization (~1000-5000ms), totaling 2-8 seconds typically.

## Multi-Container Architecture

A Cloud Run instance always has one single ingress container that listens for requests, and optionally one or more sidecar containers. Cloud Run sidecars allow you to start independent sidecar containers that run alongside the main container serving web requests.

## Key Considerations for Sidecars and Cold Start

While the search results don't explicitly detail the additional latency impact specifically caused by sidecar containers during cold starts, they do provide important context:

- Cloud Run always allocates CPU to all containers, including sidecars within a worker pool instance.
- Requests will be sent to the ingress container as soon as it is listening on the configured port. This suggests sidecars must also complete their startup before the ingress container can fully serve traffic.
- You can enable startup CPU boost to temporarily increase CPU allocation during instance startup in order to reduce startup latency.

## Communication Between Containers

All containers within an instance share the same network namespace and can communicate with each other over localhost:port, and the containers can also share files via shared volumes.

The search results suggest that for optimal performance, you should consider using startup CPU boost and keeping both the ingress container and any sidecars lightweight to minimize overall cold start duration.

Links: [{"title":"Password Management for Teams & Small Business | 1Password","url":"https://1password.com/product/teams-small-business-password-manager"},{"title":"Pricing Plans for the Best Password Manager | 1Password","url":"https://1password.com/pricing/password-manager"},{"title":"1Password Business Review 2025: Features, Pros & Cons - KDnuggets","url":"https://www.kdnuggets.com/review/1password-business"},{"title":"1Password Pricing Guide: Plans, Features, and Business Savings Tips","url":"https://www.spendflo.com/blog/1password-pricing-the-ultimate-guide"},{"title":"About 1Password subscription billing | 1Password Support","url":"https://support.1password.com/membership-billing-policy/"},{"title":"1Password Pricing in 2026: Detailed Comparison","url":"https://cybernews.com/best-password-managers/1password-review/1password-pricing/"},{"title":"Teams and business | 1Password Support","url":"https://support.1password.com/category/teams/"},{"title":"1Password Pricing: Plans, Costs, and Features Explained","url":"https://www.securden.com/blog/1password-pricing-review.html"},{"title":"Families vs. Pro (Launch Special) Plan vs. Teams Starter Pack vs. Business. â€” 1Password Community","url":"https://1password.community/discussion/146027/families-vs-pro-launch-special-plan-vs-teams-starter-pack-vs-business"},{"title":"Team members: Get started with 1Password | 1Password Support","url":"https://support.1password.com/explore/team-member/"}]

Perfect! I found the information needed. Let me search for one more confirmation about service accounts availability across all plans.

No links found.

Based on my search results, I have found comprehensive information about 1Password Service Accounts and their availability. Here's what I found:

## 1Password Service Accounts Availability

1Password Developer is part of every plan including Individual, Family, Teams, Business, and Enterprise. This means Service Accounts are not limited to Business only.

With 1Password Teams and 1Password Business, you can manage who on your team can create service accounts and which vaults the service accounts can access. By default, only owners and administrators can create and manage service accounts in 1Password Teams and 1Password Business.

### Developer Documentation

The official 1Password developer documentation covers Service Accounts comprehensively at developer.1password.com. Service accounts are used to automate scripts to manage secrets. Using a service account helps you implement the principal of least privilege and avoid the limitations of personal accounts (for example, SSO and MFA requirements).

### Key Points:
- 1Password Service Accounts have hourly and daily rate limits that vary by tier (Individual or Family, Teams, and Business).
- With 1Password Teams and 1Password Business, you can manage who on your team can create service accounts, indicating both plans support this feature

So to directly answer your question: Service Accounts are **included across all 1Password plans**, not just Business. However, rate limits vary by subscription tier.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

1â†’SCRIPT_DIR="$(cd "$(dirname "$0")" && pwd)"
     2â†’SDZ_SAMPLE_DIR="${SCRIPT_DIR}/sample"
     3â†’export SDZ_SAMPLE_DIR
     4â†’
     5â†’cat <<'EOF' > /tmp/sdz_seed_spots.sh
     6â†’#!/usr/bin/env bash
     7â†’set -euo pipefail
     8â†’
     9â†’# ===== å¿…è¦ãªç’°å¢ƒå¤‰æ•° =====
    10â†’# .env ã‚’èª­ã‚“ã§ã„ã‚‹å‰æ
    11â†’: "${YOUR_FIREBASE_WEB_API_KEY:?missing}"
    12â†’: "${TEST_USER_ID:?missing}"
    13â†’: "${TEST_USER_PASSWORD:?missing}"
    14â†’: "${SDZ_API_URL:?missing}"
    15â†’: "${SDZ_SAMPLE_DIR:?missing}"
    16â†’
    17â†’SDZ_PROJECT_ID="sdz-dev"
    18â†’
    19â†’# Firestore RESTç”¨ãƒˆãƒ¼ã‚¯ãƒ³ï¼ˆå‰Šé™¤å‡¦ç†ã«ã®ã¿ä½¿ç”¨ï¼‰
    20â†’FIRESTORE_TOKEN="$(gcloud auth print-access-token)"
    21â†’
    22â†’# Firebase IDãƒˆãƒ¼ã‚¯ãƒ³å–å¾—ï¼ˆAPIç”¨ï¼‰
    23â†’payload="$(jq -n --arg email "${TEST_USER_ID}" --arg password "${TEST_USER_PASSWORD}" \
    24â†’  '{email:$email,password:$password,returnSecureToken:true}')"
    25â†’
    26â†’SDZ_ID_TOKEN="$(curl -sS \
    27â†’  "https://identitytoolkit.googleapis.com/v1/accounts:signInWithPassword?key=${YOUR_FIREBASE_WEB_API_KEY}" \
    28â†’  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
    29â†’  -d "${payload}" | jq -r '.idToken')"
    30â†’
    31â†’echo "ID token length: ${#SDZ_ID_TOKEN}"
    32â†’
    33â†’# ===== 0) APIç–é€šç¢ºèª =====
    34â†’health_status="$(curl -sS -o /dev/null -w "%{http_code}" "${SDZ_API_URL}/sdz/health")"
    35â†’if [ "${health_status}" != "200" ]; then
    36â†’  echo "ERROR: API health check failed (HTTP ${health_status})"
    37â†’  exit 1
    38â†’fi
    39â†’
    40â†’# ===== 1) Firestore /spots ã‚’å…¨å‰Šé™¤ =====
    41â†’echo "Delete all spots..."
    42â†’list="$(curl -sS -H "Authorization: Bearer ${FIRESTORE_TOKEN}" \
    43â†’  "https://firestore.googleapis.com/v1/projects/${SDZ_PROJECT_ID}/databases/(default)/documents/spots?pageSize=200")"
    44â†’
    45â†’echo "${list}" | jq -r '.documents[]?.name' | while read -r doc; do
    46â†’  id="$(echo "${doc}" | awk -F/ '{print $NF}')"
    47â†’  curl -sS -X DELETE \
    48â†’    "https://firestore.googleapis.com/v1/projects/${SDZ_PROJECT_ID}/databases/(default)/documents/spots/${id}" \
    49â†’    -H "Authorization: Bearer ${FIRESTORE_TOKEN}" >/dev/null
    50â†’  echo "deleted ${id}"
    51â†’done
    52â†’
    53â†’# ===== 2) ç”»åƒã‚¢ãƒƒãƒ—ãƒ­ãƒ¼ãƒ‰ â†’ APIã§ã‚¹ãƒãƒƒãƒˆä½œæˆ =====
    54â†’spots=(
    55â†’  "dev-smoke-1|${SDZ_SAMPLE_DIR}/dev-smoke-1.png|35.6812|139.7671"
    56â†’  "dev-smoke-2|${SDZ_SAMPLE_DIR}/dev-smoke-2.png|35.6812|139.7671"
    57â†’  "dev-smoke-3|${SDZ_SAMPLE_DIR}/dev-smoke-3.png|35.6812|139.7671"
    58â†’  "dev-smoke-spot|${SDZ_SAMPLE_DIR}/dev-smoke-spot.png|35.6812|139.7671"
    59â†’)
    60â†’
    61â†’for item in "${spots[@]}"; do
    62â†’  IFS='|' read -r name file lat lng <<< "${item}"
    63â†’
    64â†’  echo "upload url: ${name}"
    65â†’  upload="$(curl -sS -X POST "${SDZ_API_URL}/sdz/spots/upload-url" \
    66â†’    -H "Authorization: Bearer ${SDZ_ID_TOKEN}" \
    67â†’    -H "X-SDZ-Client: ios" \
    68â†’    -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
    69â†’    -d '{"contentType":"image/png"}')"
    70â†’
    71â†’  upload_url="$(echo "${upload}" | jq -r '.uploadUrl')"
    72â†’  object_url="$(echo "${upload}" | jq -r '.objectUrl')"
    73â†’
    74â†’  if [ -z "${upload_url}" ] || [ "${upload_url}" = "null" ]; then
    75â†’    echo "ERROR: uploadUrl missing for ${name}"
    76â†’    echo "${upload}"
    77â†’    exit 1
    78â†’  fi
    79â†’
    80â†’  curl -sS -X PUT "${upload_url}" \
    81â†’    -H "Content-Type: image/png" \
    82â†’    --upload-file "${file}" > /dev/null
    83â†’
    84â†’  body="$(jq -n \
    85â†’    --arg name "${name}" \
    86â†’    --arg desc "dev seed data" \
    87â†’    --argjson lat "${lat}" \
    88â†’    --argjson lng "${lng}" \
    89â†’    --arg url "${object_url}" \
    90â†’    '{name:$name,description:$desc,location:{lat:$lat,lng:$lng},tags:["smoke","dev"],images:[$url]}')"
    91â†’
    92â†’  curl -sS -X POST "${SDZ_API_URL}/sdz/spots" \
    93â†’    -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
    94â†’    -H "Authorization: Bearer ${SDZ_ID_TOKEN}" \
    95â†’    -H "X-SDZ-Client: ios" \
    96â†’    -d "${body}" | jq '.spotId'
    97â†’
    98â†’  echo "seeded: ${name}"
    99â†’done

   102â†’bash /tmp/sdz_seed_spots.sh
   103â†’

# load-secrets-action ã®ä½¿ç”¨ã‚¬ã‚¤ãƒ‰

## æ¦‚è¦
`load-secrets-action`ã¯1Passwordã‹ã‚‰ GitHub Actionsã«ã‚·ãƒ¼ã‚¯ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆã‚’ãƒ­ãƒ¼ãƒ‰ã™ã‚‹ã‚¢ã‚¯ã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ã§ã™ã€‚"Service Accounts or 1Password Connect"ã®èªè¨¼æ–¹æ³•ã«å¯¾å¿œã—ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚

## èªè¨¼æ–¹æ³•
- **Service Accounts**: 1Passwordã®ã‚µãƒ¼ãƒ“ã‚¹ã‚¢ã‚«ã‚¦ãƒ³ãƒˆèªè¨¼
- **1Password Connect**: ConnectçµŒç”±ã®èªè¨¼

## åŸºæœ¬çš„ãªè¨­å®šä¾‹

### æ–¹æ³•1: ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒƒãƒ—ã®å‡ºåŠ›ã¨ã—ã¦ã‚·ãƒ¼ã‚¯ãƒ¬ãƒƒãƒˆã‚’ã‚¨ã‚¯ã‚¹ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆï¼ˆæ¨å¥¨ï¼‰
```yaml

  id: load_secrets
  uses: 1password/load-secrets-action@v3
  env:
    OP_SERVICE_ACCOUNT_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.OP_SERVICE_ACCOUNT_TOKEN }}
    SECRET: op://app-cicd/hello-world/secret
    OP_ENV_FILE: "./path/to/.env.tpl"

- name: Print masked secret

```

### æ–¹æ³•2: ç’°å¢ƒå¤‰æ•°ã¨ã—ã¦ã‚¨ã‚¯ã‚¹ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆ

    SECRET: op://app-cicd/hello-world/secret

1â†’name: Extract Lessons from PR
     2â†’
     3â†’on:
     4â†’  pull_request:
     5â†’    types: [closed]
     6â†’  workflow_dispatch:
     7â†’    inputs:
     8â†’      pr_number:
     9â†’        description: "æ•™è¨“ã‚’æŠ½å‡ºã™ã‚‹PRç•ªå·"
    10â†’        required: true
    11â†’        type: number
    12â†’
    13â†’jobs:
    14â†’  extract-lessons:
    15â†’    if: >
    16â†’      (github.event_name == 'workflow_dispatch') ||
    17â†’      (github.event.pull_request.merged == true &&
    18â†’       contains(github.event.pull_request.labels.*.name, 'lesson'))
    19â†’    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    20â†’    permissions:
    21â†’      contents: write
    22â†’      pull-requests: write
    23â†’      id-token: write
    24â†’
    25â†’    steps:
    26â†’      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
    27â†’        with:
    28â†’          ref: main
    29â†’          fetch-depth: 0
    30â†’
    31â†’      - name: Resolve PR number
    32â†’        id: pr
    33â†’        env:
    34â†’          GH_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
    35â†’        run: |
    36â†’          PR_NUMBER="${{ github.event.pull_request.number || github.event.inputs.pr_number }}"
    37â†’          echo "number=${PR_NUMBER}" >> "$GITHUB_OUTPUT"
    38â†’          PR_TITLE=$(gh pr view "$PR_NUMBER" --json title --jq '.title')
    39â†’          echo "title=${PR_TITLE}" >> "$GITHUB_OUTPUT"
    40â†’
    41â†’      - name: Gather PR context
    42â†’        env:
    43â†’          GH_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
    44â†’          PR_NUMBER: ${{ steps.pr.outputs.number }}
    45â†’        run: |
    46â†’          mkdir -p /tmp/pr-context
    47â†’
    48â†’          gh pr view "$PR_NUMBER" --json title,body,labels,files \
    49â†’            > /tmp/pr-context/pr-metadata.json
    50â†’
    51â†’          gh api "repos/${{ github.repository }}/pulls/${PR_NUMBER}/comments" \
    52â†’            --paginate > /tmp/pr-context/review-comments.json
    53â†’
    54â†’          gh api "repos/${{ github.repository }}/pulls/${PR_NUMBER}/reviews" \
    55â†’            --paginate > /tmp/pr-context/reviews.json
    56â†’
    57â†’          gh api "repos/${{ github.repository }}/issues/${PR_NUMBER}/comments" \
    58â†’            --paginate > /tmp/pr-context/discussion.json
    59â†’
    60â†’          gh pr diff "$PR_NUMBER" > /tmp/pr-context/diff.patch || true
    61â†’
    62â†’      - uses: anthropics/claude-code-action@v1
    63â†’        with:
    64â†’          claude_code_oauth_token: ${{ secrets.CLAUDE_CODE_OAUTH_TOKEN }}
    65â†’          prompt: |
    66â†’            ## ã‚¿ã‚¹ã‚¯
    67â†’
    68â†’            PR #${{ steps.pr.outputs.number }} "${{ steps.pr.outputs.title }}" ã‹ã‚‰æ•™è¨“ã‚’æŠ½å‡ºã— CLAUDE.md ã‚’æ›´æ–°ã™ã‚‹ã€‚
    69â†’
    70â†’            ## ã‚³ãƒ³ãƒ†ã‚­ã‚¹ãƒˆ
    71â†’
    72â†’            ä»¥ä¸‹ã®ãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚¤ãƒ«ã«PRã®æƒ…å ±ãŒã‚ã‚‹:
    73â†’            - /tmp/pr-context/pr-metadata.json (ã‚¿ã‚¤ãƒˆãƒ«ã€æœ¬æ–‡ã€å¤‰æ›´ãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚¤ãƒ«)
    74â†’            - /tmp/pr-context/review-comments.json (ã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒ©ã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒ¬ãƒ“ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ã‚³ãƒ¡ãƒ³ãƒˆ)
    75â†’            - /tmp/pr-context/reviews.json (ãƒ¬ãƒ“ãƒ¥ãƒ¼æœ¬æ–‡)
    76â†’            - /tmp/pr-context/discussion.json (PRä¸Šã®ãƒ‡ã‚£ã‚¹ã‚«ãƒƒã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³)
    77â†’            - /tmp/pr-context/diff.patch (ã‚³ãƒ¼ãƒ‰å·®åˆ†)
    78â†’
    79â†’            ## æ‰‹é †
    80â†’
    81â†’            1. ä¸Šè¨˜ã®ã‚³ãƒ³ãƒ†ã‚­ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚¤ãƒ«ã‚’å…¨ã¦èª­ã‚€

    86â†’               - è¨­è¨ˆåˆ¤æ–­ã¨ãã®ç†ç”±

1â†’# spot-diggzçµ±åˆé–‹ç™ºç’°å¢ƒ
     2â†’# Rust + TypeScript/React + Terraform + GCPç’°å¢ƒ
     3â†’
     4â†’FROM mcr.microsoft.com/vscode/devcontainers/base:ubuntu-22.04
     5â†’
     6â†’# ç’°å¢ƒå¤‰æ•°è¨­å®š
     7â†’ENV DEBIAN_FRONTEND=noninteractive
     8â†’ENV RUST_VERSION=1.90.0
     9â†’ENV NODE_VERSION=20.10.0
    10â†’ENV TERRAFORM_VERSION=1.6.6
    11â†’ENV GCLOUD_VERSION=456.0.0
    12â†’
    13â†’# ãƒ‘ãƒƒã‚±ãƒ¼ã‚¸ã‚¢ãƒƒãƒ—ãƒ‡ãƒ¼ãƒˆãƒ»åŸºæœ¬ãƒ„ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ¼ãƒ«
    14â†’RUN apt-get update && apt-get install -y \
    15â†’    curl \
    16â†’    wget \
    17â†’    git \
    18â†’    build-essential \
    19â†’    pkg-config \
    20â†’    libssl-dev \
    21â†’    libsqlite3-dev \
    22â†’    postgresql-client \
    23â†’    redis-tools \
    24â†’    jq \
    25â†’    unzip \
    26â†’    vim \
    27â†’    htop \
    28â†’    tree \
    29â†’    ca-certificates \
    30â†’    gnupg \
    31â†’    lsb-release \
    32â†’    && rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/*
    33â†’
    34â†’# Docker CLI ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ¼ãƒ«
    35â†’RUN curl -fsSL https://download.docker.com/linux/ubuntu/gpg | gpg --dearmor -o /usr/share/keyrings/docker-archive-keyring.gpg \
    36â†’    && echo "deb [arch=$(dpkg --print-architecture) signed-by=/usr/share/keyrings/docker-archive-keyring.gpg] https://download.docker.com/linux/ubuntu $(lsb_release -cs) stable" | tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/docker.list > /dev/null \
    37â†’    && apt-get update \
    38â†’    && apt-get install -y docker-ce-cli \
    39â†’    && rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/*
    40â†’
    41â†’# Rust toolchain ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ¼ãƒ«
    42â†’RUN curl --proto '=https' --tlsv1.2 -sSf https://sh.rustup.rs | sh -s -- -y --default-toolchain ${RUST_VERSION} \
    43â†’    && . $HOME/.cargo/env \
    44â†’    && rustup component add rustfmt clippy rust-analyzer
    45â†’
    46â†’# Node.js & npm ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ¼ãƒ« (nvmã‚’ä½¿ç”¨)
    47â†’RUN curl -o- https://raw.githubusercontent.com/nvm-sh/nvm/v0.39.0/install.sh | bash \
    48â†’    && . ~/.nvm/nvm.sh \
    49â†’    && nvm install ${NODE_VERSION} \
    50â†’    && nvm use ${NODE_VERSION} \
    51â†’    && nvm alias default ${NODE_VERSION} \
    52â†’    && npm install -g yarn pnpm @angular/cli create-react-app
    53â†’
    54â†’# Terraform ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ¼ãƒ«
    55â†’RUN wget https://releases.hashicorp.com/terraform/${TERRAFORM_VERSION}/terraform_${TERRAFORM_VERSION}_linux_amd64.zip \
    56â†’    && unzip terraform_${TERRAFORM_VERSION}_linux_amd64.zip \
    57â†’    && mv terraform /usr/local/bin/ \
    58â†’    && rm terraform_${TERRAFORM_VERSION}_linux_amd64.zip
    59â†’
    60â†’# Google Cloud CLI ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ¼ãƒ«
    61â†’RUN curl https://dl.google.com/dl/cloudsdk/channels/rapid/downloads/google-cloud-cli-${GCLOUD_VERSION}-linux-x86_64.tar.gz | tar -xz -C /opt \
    62â†’    && /opt/google-cloud-sdk/install.sh --quiet --usage-reporting=false --path-update=true \
    63â†’    && ln -s /opt/google-cloud-sdk/bin/* /usr/local/bin/
    64â†’
    65â†’# VSCode Serverã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ¼ãƒ«ï¼ˆCodespacesã§è‡ªå‹•çš„ã«å‡¦ç†ã•ã‚Œã‚‹ãŒã€å¿µã®ãŸã‚ï¼‰
    66â†’RUN curl -fsSL https://code-server.dev/install.sh | sh -s -- --dry-run
    67â†’
    68â†’# é–‹ç™ºç”¨ãƒ„ãƒ¼ãƒ«ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ¼ãƒ«
    69â†’RUN . ~/.nvm/nvm.sh \
    70â†’    && npm install -g \
    71â†’    eslint \
    72â†’    prettier \
    73â†’    typescript \
    74â†’    ts-node \
    75â†’    @types/node \
    76â†’    concurrently \
    77â†’    nodemon
    78â†’
    79â†’# Rusté–‹ç™ºãƒ„ãƒ¼ãƒ«è¿½åŠ ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¹ãƒˆãƒ¼ãƒ«
    80â†’# cargo-binstallã§äº‹å‰ãƒ“ãƒ«ãƒ‰æ¸ˆã¿ãƒã‚¤ãƒŠãƒªã‚’å„ªå…ˆã—ã€CIã®ãƒ¡ãƒ¢ãƒªè² è·ã‚’è»½æ¸›ã™ã‚‹
    81â†’RUN . $HOME/.cargo/env \
    82â†’    && curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/cargo-bins/cargo-binstall/main/install-from-binstall-release.sh | bash \
    83â†’    && cargo binstall -y \
    84â†’    cargo-watch \
    85â†’    cargo-edit \
    86â†’    cargo-audit \
    87â†’    cargo-outdated \
    88â†’    wasm-pack
    89â†’
    90â†’# ä½œæ¥­ãƒ‡ã‚£ãƒ¬ã‚¯ãƒˆãƒªè¨­å®š
    91â†’WORKDIR /workspace
    92â†’
    93â†’# é–‹ç™ºç”¨ã‚¹ã‚¯ãƒªãƒ—ãƒˆã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼
    94â†’COPY .devcontainer/setup.sh /workspace/.devcontainer/setup.sh
    95â†’RUN chmod +x /workspace/.devcontainer/setup.sh
    96â†’
    97â†’# ãƒ¦ãƒ¼ã‚¶ãƒ¼è¨­å®šï¼ˆCodespacesã§ã¯vscodeãƒ¦ãƒ¼ã‚¶ãƒ¼ãŒãƒ‡ãƒ•ã‚©ãƒ«ãƒˆï¼‰
    98â†’RUN groupadd -r docker || true \
    99â†’    && usermod -aG docker vscode \
   100â†’    && echo 'export PATH="$HOME/.cargo/bin:$PATH"' >> /home/vscode/.bashrc \
   101â†’    && echo 'export PATH="$HOME/.nvm/versions/node/v${NODE_VERSION}/bin:$PATH"' >> /home/vscode/.bashrc \
   102â†’    && echo 'source ~/.nvm/nvm.sh' >> /home/vscode/.bashrc \
   103â†’    && echo 'source $HOME/.cargo/env' >> /home/vscode/.bashrc
   104â†’
   105â†’# zshè¨­å®šï¼ˆoh-my-zshã¯devcontainer featuresã§å‡¦ç†ï¼‰
   106â†’RUN echo 'export PATH="$HOME/.cargo/bin:$PATH"' >> /home/vscode/.zshrc \
   107â†’    && echo 'export PATH="$HOME/.nvm/versions/node/v${NODE_VERSION}/bin:$PATH"' >> /home/vscode/.zshrc \
   108â†’    && echo 'source ~/.nvm/nvm.sh' >> /home/vscode/.zshrc \
   109â†’    && echo 'source $HOME/.cargo/env' >> /home/vscode/.zshrc
   110â†’
   111â†’# æ¨©é™è¨­å®š
   112â†’RUN chown -R vscode:vscode /home/vscode \
   113â†’    && chmod 755 /home/vscode
   114â†’
   115â†’USER vscode
   116â†’
   117â†’# ç’°å¢ƒå¤‰æ•°ã®æœ€çµ‚è¨­å®š
   118â†’ENV PATH="/home/vscode/.cargo/bin:/home/vscode/.nvm/versions/node/v${NODE_VERSION}/bin:/opt/google-cloud-sdk/bin:${PATH}"
   119â†’
   120â†’# ãƒ˜ãƒ«ã‚¹ãƒã‚§ãƒƒã‚¯
   121â†’HEALTHCHECK --interval=30s --timeout=10s --start-period=5s --retries=3 \
   122â†’    CMD curl -f http://localhost:3000/ || exit 1
   123â†’

1â†’import Foundation
     2â†’import Combine
     3â†’
     4â†’enum SdzTab: Hashable {
     5â†’    case spots
     6â†’    case list
     7â†’    case settings
     8â†’}
     9â†’
    10â†’/// Shared application state used across the entire app.
    11â†’@MainActor
    12â†’final class SdzAppState: ObservableObject {
    13â†’    /// Flag indicating whether the user is authenticated.
    14â†’    @Published var isAuthenticated: Bool = false
    15â†’
    16â†’    /// Currently selected API environment.
    17â†’    let environment: SdzEnvironment = .dev
    18â†’
    19â†’    /// Placeholder for the authentication token (Firebase ID token).
    20â†’    @Published var idToken: String?
    21â†’
    22â†’    /// Current authenticated user info (from Firebase).
    23â†’    @Published var authUserId: String?
    24â†’    @Published var authEmail: String?
    25â†’    @Published var authDisplayName: String?
    26â†’    @Published var authProviderIds: [String] = []
    27â†’
    28â†’    /// Indicates whether the auth session is loading.
    29â†’    @Published var isAuthLoading: Bool = false
    30â†’
    31â†’    /// Favorites synced with backend (cached locally).
    32â†’    @Published private(set) var favoriteSpots: [SdzSpot] = []
    33â†’    @Published var isFavoritesLoading: Bool = false
    34â†’    @Published var favoritesErrorMessage: String?
    35â†’
    36â†’    /// Profile image data stored locally.
    37â†’    @Published var profileImageData: Data?
    38â†’
    39â†’    /// Currently selected tab.
    40â†’    @Published var selectedTab: SdzTab = .spots
    41â†’    @Published var isPostComposerPresented: Bool = false
    42â†’
    43â†’    /// Indicates whether the post or edit screen is currently visible.
    44â†’    @Published var isPostingSpot: Bool = false
    45â†’    @Published var isEditingSpot: Bool = false
    46â†’
    47â†’    /// Draft location passed from map to the post flow.
    48â†’    @Published var draftPostLocation: SdzSpotLocation?
    49â†’
    50â†’    /// Pending official URL shared from external apps.
    51â†’    @Published var pendingOfficialUrl: String?
    52â†’
    53â†’    /// Pending spot location shared from external map apps.
    54â†’    @Published var pendingSharedLocation: SdzSpotLocation?
    55â†’    @Published var pendingSharedLocationName: String?
    56â†’    @Published var pendingSharedLocationError: String?
    57â†’    @Published var pendingSharedLocationForEdit: SdzSpotLocation?
    58â†’    @Published var pendingSharedLocationNameForEdit: String?
    59â†’    @Published var pendingSharedLocationErrorForEdit: String?
    60â†’
    61â†’    /// Pending location to focus on the map when sharing from external apps.
    62â†’    @Published var pendingMapFocusLocation: SdzSpotLocation?
    63â†’    @Published var pendingMapFocusName: String?
    64â†’
    65â†’    /// Pending selection when no return context is available.
    66â†’    @Published var pendingShareSelectionLocation: SdzSpotLocation?
    67â†’    @Published var pendingShareSelectionName: String?
    68â†’    @Published var isShareSelectionPromptVisible: Bool = false
    69â†’
    70â†’    private enum SharedDefaults {
    71â†’        static let appGroupId = "group.ios-sdz-fb-dev"
    72â†’        static let payloadKey = "sdz.shared-payload"
    73â†’    }
    74â†’    private static let universalLinkHost = "sdz-dev-api-1053202159855.asia-northeast1.run.app"
    75â†’
    76â†’    enum SdzShareReturnContext: String, Codable {
    77â†’        case post
    78â†’        case edit
    79â†’        case map
    80â†’    }
